loans.name: Annielice

texts.en:
Annielice R., 54, is from the village of Punit. She is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Annielice owns & operates a  manufacturing business. Her business earns income primarily from manufacturing & selling clothing products to local businesses and community members. Annielice has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Annielice joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annielice has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Annielice is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase more raw materials. This loan will be Annielice's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be his first from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
In 2007, Lolita joined ASHI, a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in order to secure access to capital for her business, which consists of raising hogs. This loan is her third, and she has repaid the previous loans on time and made good use of them to expand her business and her income.

Lolita has applied for a new loan of PHP 13,000 to buy sacks of feed and vitamins and to pay for transportation expenses.

Lolita dreams of expanding her business into a full-fledged pig farm. She also dreams of sending her grandchildren to school until they finish college and find good jobs. Until that happens, she is pleased at the way in which ASHI and Kiva have changed her family's life and given them the potential to make their dreams come true.

loans.use: To buy sacks of feed and vitamins and to pay for transportation expenses

This loan will be her 10th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children’s tuition fees. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. loans.name: Rwemiyaga Tungukye, Ntungamo Group

texts.en:
Very hard working B. James has been operating a produce sales business from Rwemiyaga, Ntungamo for a period of eight years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of two school-going children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as the business now earns only 200,000 Ugandan shillings in sharp contrast to the previous earnings.
 
People in western Uganda, despite laboring in such tough circumstances, always find a way of educating their children. James is no exception. He now looks forward to the prospect of enhancing his business by buying fertilizer and mulches for his plantation. He has other income-generating activities like coffee sales, firewood sales and timber. With this loan, he will increase his income and become better able to support his family.

loans.use: Buying fertilizers and mulches

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a married woman with two children, a boy and a girl who both attend school. Her husband works in the hotel industry and he contributes to his family's needs. Eunice rents a house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

Eunice has been operating an open food market business for the last five years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. With this KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase a bundle of cooking flour, 50 kg of cooking oil and a sack of beans. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to open a restaurant in the future. Eunice decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans.

loans.use: To purchase cooking flour, cooking oil and beans

loans.name: Ella

texts.en:
This Kiva-funded borrower is a 46-year old married woman from San Jose in the province of Antique, living with her husband and nine children. In 1998, she opened her own welding shop business. Her avid customers come from the surrounding areas and nearby town

Ella is now requesting a loan of 30,000 Philippine pesos in order to purchase additional equipment for her welding shop. She believes that having new equipment at her welding shop will help her retain her current customers as well as attract new clients.   Ella has been a proud member of Kiva field partner Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI) since 1998.  She has been a dedicated member who has a regular weekly center meeting attendance has a solid records of repayments on previous loans.

Ella’s dreams are for her children to be able to complete college, for her to have winning business, and to build a comfortable home in which to live.

loans.use: To purchase equipment for a welding shop.

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie R. is from the village of Olango. She is 32 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lenie owns and operates a a furniture-making business from which she sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Lenie has had her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Lenie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services with the hope of improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lenie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. Lenie is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings.  She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials for a furniture-making business.

loans.name: Kikozza Women's Development Group - Mityana

texts.en:
On the strength of her hard work-driven approach and her courage of conviction, 35-year-old Jane N. has obtained a strong business niche for her beauty salon business in Kiryokya-Mityana.  By and large she has used her strength of character to forestall and overcome the inevitable challenges that come with operating her nine-year-old business. That has been her reliable winning calling card.

Jane also ekes out side profits from a retail business enterprise. In a given week, Jane says she makes profits that amount to about 35,000 Ugandan shillings. With her share of this loan to the  Kikozza Women's Development Group, whose members are pictured in the photo that accompanies this profile, Jane envisages being in a better position to buy more cosmetics and other salon equipment like hair weaving implements for her salon.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and hair weaving implements for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Jabor

texts.ru: Шоймардонов Чабор проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 47 лет. Женат, имеет двоих детей. Жена работает в колхозе. Сам Чабор занимается выращиванием риса. В этой области имеет богатый опыт. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Он хочет посеет и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Jabor S. lives in the town of Tursunzade. He is 47 years old, married and has two children. His wife works on a collective farm. On his own, Jabor grows rice. He has rich experience in this area. The loan will be used to purchase mineral fertilizers. He wants plant seeds and receive a good harvest to sell.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizers

loans.name: Erick

texts.en:
Erick is a married man with an eight-month-old son. His wife runs a vegetable stall and she contributes to the family's basic needs. He has been operating his business of cultivating maize and selling it at a profit for the last four years.  Erick sells at the market and from home to neighbors and passersby. In addition he has motorcycle for transport, contributing to his other sources of income.

With this 40,000 kenya shilling loan, he wants to expand his farm and buy a pumping machine for irrigation. Erick faces the major challenge of seasonality and transportation in his business. He hopes to buy his own plot of land and build rental houses in future. He decided to work with Yehu so as to access loans and improve his living standard.  Erick owns a house, with no electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food, medication and clothing.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine to irrigate a farm.

loans.name: Analou

texts.en:
Analou A. is from the town of Talibon. She is 35 years old, married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Analou runs a general store. from which she sells a variety of different products to residents of the local community. Analou has been engaged in her business for over two years. She says one of the reasons she works hard is for her to be able to save for her children's education.

Analou joined CEVI to gain access to financial services with the hopes of improving her living situation and the ability to better engage in business activities. Analou is requesting her first loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, which she plans to use to buy additional products to sell.  She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of taking this loan to supplement her family's income and improve their house. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell in a general store.

loans.name: Djelika's Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Dembagnouma I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 39 ans et  en  moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des familles polygames à Wobougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé
Avec ce nouveau prêt, DJENEBA F. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide et de haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40.000FCFA environ en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Dembagnouma I group are married women with an average age of 39 and an average of 3 children. They live in polygamous families in Wobougou, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their rainy season activities. They grow, among other crops, rice, pearl millet, peanuts, and beans. They are on their second season loan and their previous loan was repaid in full. With this new loan, Djeneba F. plans on buying fertilizer, small farming equipment, and paying for the labor costs involved in maintaining approximately 1 hectare of peanuts and beans. The harvested crops are sold in Dioïla and Massigui to a client base made up of both men and women. The group members hope to make an average profit of approximately 40,000 francs CFA by the end of the season.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, and small farming equipment

loans.name: Annalinda

texts.en:
Annalinda C. is from the town of Talibon. She is 35 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. She is involved in the fishing business. She helps her husband operate their fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish at the market. When not fishing, she spends time cooking food that she sells in their community. She hopes to have a stable income to sustain their children's education.

Annalinda joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Annalinda has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets and also additional ingredients for making food. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Annalinda from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay her children's tuition fees and improve their living conditions.

loans.name: Dembagnouma Ii Group

texts.fr:
Constitué de dix femmes  toutes mariées, le membres du groupe Dembagnouma II  ont en moyenne 29 ans, en moyenne 3 enfants et  vivent dans des familles polygames à Wobougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, MARAMOU D. compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,8 hectare  d’arachide.
La production est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla ou Massigui après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 75.000FCFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The Dembagnouma II group is composed of 10 married women with an average age of 29, an average of 3 children, and they live in polygamous families in Wobougou, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their rainy season activities. They grow, among other crops, rice, pearl millet, peanuts, and beans. They are on their second seasonal loan and their previous loan was repaid in full. With this new loan, Maramou D. plans on buying fertilizer and small farming equipment, and paying the labor costs involved in maintaining approximately 1.8 hectares of peanuts. The harvested crops are sold in Dioïla or Massigui to a client base made up of both men and women. She hopes to make a profit of 75,000 francs CFA by the end of the season.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, and small farming equipment

texts.en:

In 2009, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Dembagnouma  Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe Dembagnouma III sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 33 ans et  en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans les familles polygames à Wobougou, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées par le groupe sont le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SATA F., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environ 1,9 hectare d’arachide.
La production  est vendue au niveau de la ville de Dioïla après les récoltes à une clientèle composée de revendeurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 80.000FCFA  en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The Dembagnouma III group is composed of 10 married women with an average age of 33, an average of 2 children, and they live in polygamous families in Wobougou, one of the villages in the Dioïla prefecture, in the Koulikoro region, the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to better organize their rainy season activities. They grow rice, pearl millet, peanuts, and beans. They are on their second seasonal loan and their previous loan was repaid in full. With this new loan, Sata F., the president of the group, plans on buying fertilizer and small farming equipment, and paying the labor costs involved in maintaining approximately 1.9 hectares of peanuts. The harvested crops are sold in Dioïla to a client base made up of merchants. She hopes to make a profit of 80,000 francs CFA by the end of the season.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont le riz, le petit mil, l’arachide et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le prêt précédent a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, SANATA D., la présidente du groupe, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1,7 hectare d’arachide.

texts.en:
The Dembagnouma V group is composed of 10 married women with an average age of 37, an average of 3 children. loans.name: Azizbuvu's Group

texts.en:
Azizbuvu H. is the leader of this group. She is 38 and married. She has three children, who are all in school.  Her older daughter is 16, and helps her parents by selling fruits at the market.  Azizbuvu takes orders and sews national cloth and dressmaking supplies.  Her husband works as a constructor.  Azizbuvu started this business ten years ago with the initial investment of 2000 soms and now she makes 6000 soms per month. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase fabrics and materials to sew.  In the future, she wants to expand her business, open a sewing workshop and save money to be able to give her children good education. 
Rahimahan M., 47, is married. She has four children. Her older daughter helps her mom to sell fruits and materials on the market, and her other children are in school. Two year ago Rahimahan’s mother-in-law gave her a sewing machine as a present, and since that moment, Rahimahan has sewn clothes and sells them on the market. In this way, she earns 8000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fabrics and materials, as well as fruits and vegetables in order to increase the turnover of her businesses.
Sherali A., 23, is married.  He has a three-year-old child, and his wife stays at home to take care of him.  In order to make money, Sherali sells fruits and vegetables on the market. He has been doing this for five years. In this way he earns 5000 soms per month. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase fruits and vegetables, in order to resell them at a higher price. In the future, he wants to purchase a new house to live in with his family.
Cholponoi I. is the treasurer of the group. She is 39 and married. She has two children, both of whom are at school. Cholponoi is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works in the police department.  She applied for this loan because she wants to increase the number of cattle and needs money to purchase a bull.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

 This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage.

texts.en:
Marilyn is a hardworking businesswoman who sells charcoal and fish to earn a living. She offers good service in selling her products to people in her village. She has been in this business for five years.

Marilyn belongs to a group of young entrepreneurs where she saves her money, having secured access to capital from ASHI. She appreciates that the organization has helped her improve her business, hence her standard of living. She has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to buy more charcoal and fish to sell. In the future, she hopes to buy more inventories of charcoal and fish for better sales. She sees herself venturing into a wholesale business in the next five years. Marilyn is hoping that her envisioned business will help her support her 4 children's financial needs so that they are able to graduate from college. By then, Marilyn thinks their lives would be positively changed and she will have her dreams achieved.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and fish to sell

loans.name: Asuas

texts.en: Asuas A. is currently in the business of selling crates of beer and other soft drinks in a bar and is requesting a loan to stock drinks such as wines, Red Horse, Heineken, etc. to sell. Asuas is 40 years old and married to a retired director. She has 7 children, 2 of whom attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to develop a hotel.

loans.use: to stock drinks such as wines and beers to sell

loans.name: Mary Rose

texts.en:
Mary Rose A. is from the village of Bacnor East. She is 36 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Mary Rose owns and operates a business making and selling breads, cakes and cookies to the local community. Mary Rose has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2009, Mary Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Mary Rose is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Mary Rose from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rakima's Group

texts.en:
Rakima J. is the leader of this group. She is 53 and divorced. She has raised two daughters and a son; her daughters are married and live separately with their families and her son works in a factory. Twelve years ago, with an initial investment of 10,000 KGS, Rakima started to sell vegetable oil in the market. She earns on average 10,000 KGS per month. She applied for this loan because she needs money to purchase 200 liters of oil in order to increase her business turnover. In the future, she wants to see her son get married.

Nurjan A., 33, is married. She has a son and three daughters; her son and oldest daughter attend school and the other children are not yet old enough. Nurjan is engaged in cattle breeding and her husband works in construction. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS, Nurjan bought a cow and started to breed cattle. She also sells milk to make money. She earns 2,000 KGS per month from these activities. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase a bull in order to resell it after fattening. In the future, Nurjan wants to repair her house and install new gates.

Nurzat S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 33 and divorced. She has a 13 year old daughter, who attends school. Nurzat has been engaged in cattle breeding for three years, beginning with an initial investment of 15,000 KGS. She also sells milk and earns 3,000 KGS per month from these activities. Her profits made it possible for her to improve her family's living conditions and purchase household appliances. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase sheep for breeding. In the future, Nurzat plans to purchase a vehicle.

Aida C., 26, is married. She has two daughters and a son. Her older daughter attends school and the other children are not yet old enough. Three years ago, with an initial investment of 3,000 KGS, Aida built a kiosk near her house and started to sell convenience goods. She earns 18,000 KGS per month. With money received from this loan, she wants to purchase a fridge to store goods and stationery because the school season begins and the demand will be high. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase 200 liters of vegetable oil

loans.name: Gulshan

texts.ru: Садыкова Гулшан проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 32 года. Замужем. Мать двоих детей. Муж, занимается строительными работами по найму. Сама Гулшан имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии не работала. Сейчас она занимается торговлей на рынке. Продает детскую одежду. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 3 года. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
S. Gulshan lives in the city of Qurgan-Tube. She's thirty-two years old, married and has two children. Her husband works temporary jobs in construction. Gulshan has a degree in economics, but has never worked in her profession. Currently, she sells childrens' clothes at a local market, something she has been doing for three years. She's asking for a loan to increase her goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Shakhin

texts.ru:
Shakhin G. 29 let. On ne jenat i jivet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. Shakhin uje 6 let rabotayet zubnim vrachem. Eqo otec vse vremya xotel chto bi eqo sin stal vrachem i poetomu on s detstva uchil eqo svoyey rabote. 

Shakhin  zakonchiv shkolu i posle postupil v medecinskiy kolledj. Okonchıv Kolledj spustya nekatoreye vremya Shakhin nachal rabotat  zubnim vrachem. Seychas Shakhin nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit novuyu aparaturu dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznesa.
texts.en:
Shakhin G. is twenty-nine-years-old. He is unmarried and lives in the Fuzuli region with his family. He has been a dentist for six years. His father had always wanted his son to become a doctor so he taught him his profession since he was a child. Shakhin started school after he graduated medical school. Once he finished college, after a while he started working as a dentist. Now he needs a loan for 2000 AZN to buy new equipment to advance his business.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase new equipment.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose A. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bedsheets at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock pairs of shoes and saddles to sell.  Rose is 49 years old and widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a bar.

loans.use: Stock pairs of shoes and saddles to sell

loans.name: Kasmiro

texts.en:
Kasmiro R. is currently in the business of selling ornaments, such as earrings, necklaces and weaving materials, in a salon shop. She is requesting a loan to stock more weaving materials to sell.  

Kasmiro is 25 years old and married to a student. She has one child and her child does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock more weaving materials to sell

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin A. is currently in the business of selling bread, groundnut paste and cooking oil. She is requesting a loan to stock more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell.  

Martin is 21 years old and single. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Marata

texts.en:
Marata is a single woman with one child who attends school. She has been operating her retail shop for the last six years, selling to her immediate neighbors and passersby. She has no other source of income. With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase a bundle of maize flour, wheat flour, a sack of sugar and a bundle of bathing soaps.

Marata faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future and operate a wholesale shop. She decided to work with Yehu so as to get financial support to improve her business.

She rents a house with no electricity nor piped water. She cites food as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase two bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, a sack of sugar and a bundle of bathing soaps

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose S. sells bags of charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal. Rose is 51 years old and is widowed. She has 8 children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up charcoal stores in various markets.

loans.use: to stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia A. is a 60-year-old, married woman from Sibalom, Antique. She is blessed with three children, aged 16 to 34. She is a member of Antique South East Branch. She is a very strong-minded woman and says that she works hard to better her life with the support of her husband. Despite hardships brought about by poverty, Sonia remains strong and dedicated in her pursuit to improve her family’s standard of living. Her aspiration to give her family a brighter future is what motivates her all day. To make a good living, she operates a farming business and plants vegetables. She has been engaged in this business for five years. 

She joined ASHI, a micro-finance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2006. During the course of her membership, she has been a good performer with a good credit rating (the basis of loans). She is now applying for her fourth loan of 20,000 PHP. This will be used to buy raw materials including rice seeds and fertilizers, and to cover maintenance costs of her vegetable growing. She is positive that, with access to additional working capital through ASHI and Kiva lenders, her dreams of funding her family's education will be achieved.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, fertilizers and other supplies, and to maintain her vegetable growing

loans.name: Gulasal

texts.en:
Gulasal I. llives in Kadamjai, a nice town is the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 42 and is married. She has three sons: her oldest son studies at university and the others are at school. 

Gulasal owns a shop where she sells convenience goods. Her husband went to work in Russia, so she controls all the family business by herself. Gulasal opened her shop four years ago with the initial investment of 30,000 soms and now she makes 24,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to repair her house and save money to pay for her son’s education at university. 

With this loan she wants to purchase 100kg of sugar, 30-40 packs of various drinks, vegetables, oil and other goods. In the future she plans to expand her business and purchase a vehicle to decrease her transportation costs.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase stock

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan K. retails a variety of items in her store. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar, salt and rice to sell. Susan is 20 years old and is married to a businessman. She has 1 child who does not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her shop and create another area to be used as a bar.

loans.use: to buy stock of sugar, salt and rice for resale

loans.name: Maisara

texts.en:
Maisara B. lives in Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 43 and is married. She has two daughters and a son who all attend school. 

Maisara and her husband are engaged in livestock. Two years ago, when they moved to the new house, they were given four sheep and two goats as a present. Since then, Maisara has been breeding livestock. By selling fattened sheep, she makes 4000 soms per month. 

With this loan she wants to purchase three sheep to increase her livestock numbers. She will use the rest of the loan to cover family expenses. In the future, Maisara plans to increase her livestock and save money to send her daughter to Bishkek to enter the university there.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase three sheep

loans.name: Dilfuza

texts.en: Dilfuza D. is a resident of Kadamjai, a nice town in the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is 39 and married. She has three daughters; the two older girls are at school and the youngest one is not yet. Dilfuza breeds livestock and her husband works in Russia. Dilfuza started her activity 13 years ago with the initial investment of 3,000 soms and now, selling some sheep after fattening, she makes 5,000 soms per month. That profit made it possible for her to save money to celebrate her daughter’s wedding. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase six sheep in order to increase the number of livestock she has. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase six sheep

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia O. is from the town of Talibon. She is 37 years old. Lydia is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Lydia provides photography services to local community members. She also makes photo frames. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over seven years. Lydia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the third loan taken out by Lydia from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income and improve their living conditions. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance, and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua C. cooks plain rice and jollof (spicy colored rice) at Takoradi. She is married and has two children. She has been to senior high school. Her husband is a farmer.  Ekua uses her income to support her husband in taking care of her home. Ekua will use the loan to purchase more rice to cook. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to save to build a shop where whe can sell her rice.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to cook.

loans.name: Koulossama I Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe KOULOSSAMA I  est  composé  de dix  femmes mariées du village de Nènèsso dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana, du cercle de SAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide et du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso  il y’a trois ans.
MAMOU D., qui est la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, au grand marché de Kimparana. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25 000 à 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Koulossama I est made up of 10 married women of the Nènèsso village in the former Kimparana arrondissement, in the San circle, in the Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families. They have an average age of 35 and at least 5 children. They grow peanuts and corn. In order to make their agricultural business more profitable, the group members have worked with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso for the past three years. Mamou D., the group's president, plans on using the loan to purchase a sufficient supply of peanut seeds, small farming implements, and fertilizer at the Kimparana Grand Market. After the rainy season, the harvests are stored for a certain amount of time so they can become more valuable before being sold retail (often wholesale) at the Kimparana Grand Market and surrounding markets, for cash to a client base generally from large cities. After selling their good, the group members each hope to make a profit of 25,000 to 35,000 francs CFA that will be used to pay interest on the loan and to take care of their families.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer, seeds, and small farming implements

loans.name: Shara

texts.en: Shara J. is currently in the business of selling local brew and beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Shara is 39 years old and is married with a husband that is a security guard. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar in the market premises.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan M. operates a business baking and selling local Sudanese bread (tamia and gelabia). She is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour and cooking oil. Susan is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 2 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by stocking fish to sell.

loans.use: to stock more ingredients for baking bread for resale

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man with a six-month-old son. He has been operating his poultry business for over one year. He sells wholesale and retail to restaurant operators and butcher shops. In addition, he operates a goat-meat business (buying and selling goats). 

With the Kshs 80,000 he wants to expand his poultry business by purchasing twenty broiler chicken for breeding. Joseph faces the major challenge of seasonality in his business. He hopes that, in the future, he will open another branch. His main aim of working with Yehu is to get financial assistance to improve his business. He lives in a rental house with electricity and piped water. Joseph cites his greatest monthly expense as household items.

loans.use: to purchase twenty broiler chickens

loans.name: Koulossama Ii Group

texts.fr:
KOULOSSAMA II  est un groupe constitué de  neuf femmes mariées du village de  Nènèsso,  dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana, du cercle de SAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans et au moins 5 enfants.
Elles cultivent  de l’arachide et du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y’a trois ans.  
SEGUETIO C., la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture,  au grand marché de Kimparana. 
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 25.000 à 35.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
Koulossama II is a group made up of nine married women from the village of Nènèsso in the arrondissement of Kimparana, circle of San, region of Ségou (Mali's fourth administrative region). They live in traditional families. On average, they are 35 years old and have five children. They are peanut and corn farmers. Three years ago, planning to put their farming on a sounder economic footing, they joined Soro Yiriwaso's loan program. Seguetio C., the group's president, plans on using her loan to buy peanut seed, small tools and fertilizer in the big marketplace of Kimparana. After the rains, the harvest will be stored until prices rise enough for it to be sold in the big marketplace in Kimparana and nearby markets at retail (but often wholesaled) to buyers mostly from bigger cities. The group's members hope to realize a profit of from 25,000 to 35,000 FCFA each to pay back their loans and topay for day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, small toolsand fertilizer

loans.name: Charlie

texts.en:
Charlie C. is from the town of Talibon. He is 31 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Charlie owns & operates a fishing business. He operates a fishing boat and sells the catch of assorted fish at the market. 

Charlie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. He is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the second loan taken out by Charlie from CEVI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Benkadi I Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI   est  constitué de sept hommes, tous mariés du village de Moribila Kafonon dans l’ex l’arrondissement de Kimparana du cercle de SAN, région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali). Ils   vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 37 ans et au moins 7 enfants.
Ils cultivent exclusivement du maïs. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe  ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année. 
SURDOUÉE D., compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence et d’intrants pour la production du maïs.
Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI comptent réaliser chacun, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un revenu d’environ 175 000 FCFA à 225 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group is made up of seven men who are all married and come from the village of Moribila Kafonon in the old "arrondissement" (district) of Kimparana in the San circle in the region of Ségou (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They live in traditional families and average 37 years of age with at least seven children each. They cultivate exclusively corn. Since they are concerned about making their agricultural operations profitable, the group members decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program this year. Surdouée D. is planning to use his loan to buy a sufficient quantity of seeds and intrants for his production of corn. After the winter season, the crops are stocked for a certain period of time to gain value before they are sold at the large market in Kimparana, on a retail basis (but also often wholesale) and for cash, to customers who generally come from the large towns. The members of the Benkadi group are expecting to make an income of between 175,000FCFA and 225,000 FCFA each after selling their agricultural products; this will be used for the repayment of their interest and the running costs of their families.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants and seeds

loans.name: Sergio

texts.en:
Sergio C. is from the town of Talibon. He is 36 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Sergio owns & operates a fishing business. He operates a fishing boat and sells the catch of assorted fish at the market. He has been engaged in his business for over 10 years.

Sergio joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Sergio is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement his family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama K. is a widow with five dependants. She has no educational background.  Ama prepares kenkey to sell and distribute. She also sells the uncooked maize at Takoradi. Ama uses the income she generates from her sales to educate and feed her children. Ama will use the loan to purchase more maize to cook kenkey to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to save to establish a kenkey production centre.

loans.name: Badenya Ton 1 Group

texts.fr:
Composé de quatre femmes, les membres du  groupe Badenya Ton 1 de Farabougou sont mariés majoritairement dans des familles nucléaires. Elles ont en moyenne 46 ans et 6 enfants par femme. Elles habitent le village de Farabougou dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la  région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver dans l’ensemble de l’arachide et du mil.
Madame Ténin  Traoré, la présidente du groupe, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50kg de semence d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en semence à la foire de Gouassola et en main d’œuvre avec les hommes pour les activités de labour et de désherbage avec l’association des femmes du village. 
Elle compte produire sur une superficie de 3 hectares: 10 sacs de mil et 20 sacs d’arachide. Toute la production du mil et une partie d’arachide est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu à la foire de Ségou ou sur place aux commerçants de la place. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer en condiments et en soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Ténin  Traoré a pour objectif d’acheter des petits ruminants pour s’investir dans l’élevage dans le village.
texts.en:
The Badenya Ton 1 group from Farabougou is made up of four married women, most of whom are in nuclear families. They have an average age of 46 and an average of 6 children each. They live in the village of Farabougou in the rural commune of Tesserela in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other due to marriage, kinship, and neighborly ties. In order to increase the area of their arable land, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first seasonal loan. The group members will grow peanuts and millet. Mrs. Ténin Traoré, the group's president, plans on using the loan to buy 50 kg of peanut seeds, and to pay workers to plant and weed the fields. She buys seeds at the Gouassola faire and she gets workers for the planting and weeding through association with the women of her village. In a field of 3 hectares, she hopes to produce: 10 sacks of millet and 20 sacks of peanuts. All of the millet and a part of the peanuts are consumed by the group, while the rest is sold at the Ségou fair, or on-site to merchants from the village square. The profits are used to buy condiments and to take care of the children's medical needs. Mrs. Ténin Traoré would like to buy some small ruminant animals so she can get involved in animal farming in her village.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase peanut seeds and pay workers

loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en: Nerissa H. is a married woman from the town of Talibon. She is involved in fishing. She has been helping her husband operate a fishing boat to catch and sell assorted fish to the market for three years. She also dries fish sometimes and sells those around her community. She works hard to make her business prosperous and her family happy. Nerissa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nerissa is requesting a new loan of 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This will be the first loan taken out by Nerissa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Ahmadulo

texts.ru: Имомов Ахмадуло проживает в районе Сарбанд. Возраст, 59 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена домохозяйка. Дети живут отдельно. Сам Ахмадуло занимается животноводством. Разводит скот у себя дома. Он в основном откармливает и продает крупно - рогатый скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 18 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота и комбикорма.
texts.en:
I. Ahmadulo lives the Sarband region. He's fifty-nine years old, married and has six children. His wife is a housewife and his children live separetly. Ahmadulo has bred cattle for over eighteen years. He fattens and then sells the cattle. He's asking for a loan to buy more livestock and feed compound.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy large livestock

loans.name: Badenya Ton 2 Group

texts.fr:
Composé de dix  femmes, les membres du  groupe Badenya Ton 2 sont  mariés majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 37 ans et 4 enfants par femme. Elles habitent le village de Farabougou dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er  prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver de l’arachide, du mil et du sésame.
Madame Tata  Toka  C. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 25kg de semence d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en semence à la foire de Gouassola et en main d’œuvre avec les hommes pour les activités de labour et de désherbage avec l’association des femmes du village. 
Elle compte récolter sur une superficie de 3,3 hectares: 6 sacs de mil, 17 sacs d’arachide et 2 sacs de sésame. Toute la production de mil et une partie de l’arachide est auto consommée tandis que le reste de l’arachide et le sésame sont vendus à la foire de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les petits besoins du foyer en condiments et en soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Tata  Toka  C. a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans sa famille et même dans le village.
texts.en:
The Badenya Ton 2 group is made up of 10 married women, most of whom live in large traditional families. They have an average age of 37 and an average of 4 children per woman. They live in the village of Farabougou in the rural commune of Tesserela in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali) and know each other through marriage, kinship, and neighborly ties. In order to increase the size of their crops, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first seasonal loan. The group members will grow peanuts, millet, and sesame. Mrs. Tata Toka C. plans on using the loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds, and to pay workers to work the fields. She buys seeds at the Gouassola market and she gets workers for the fields through association with the women in the village. In an area of 3.3 hectares, she plans on producing: 6 sacks of millet, 17 sacks of peanuts, and 2 sacks of sesame. All of the millet and a part of the peanuts will be consumed by the group, while the rest of the peanuts and the sesame will be sold at the Ségou market to a mixed client base. The profits will be used to buy condiments and pay for the children's medical needs. Mrs. Tata Toka C.'s goal is for her family, and even village, to become self-sufficient with regards to food.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds and pay workers

loans.name: Fayzullo

texts.ru: Одинаев Файзулло проживает в городе Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 28 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Дети маленькие. Сам Файзулло занимается торговлей. У него торговая точка рядом с центральным рынком города. Он в основном продает панели мобильных телефонов и мобильные телефоны. Этим видом деятельности занимается 5 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en:
Fayzullo O. lives in the town of Kurgan-Tiube. He is 29-years-old, married and has two children. His wife is a homemaker. His children are still small. Fayzullo is engaged in trade on his own. He has a vending booth near the central town market. He generally sells mobile telephones and accessory panels. He has been engaged in this kind of activity for five years. The loan is intended to expand his inventory.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Baktylu's Group

texts.en:
Baktylu S. is the leader of the group. She is 38, married and has four children who all attend school. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Baktylu started to sell shoes at the market. In this way she makes 10,000 soms per month. That profit has made it possible for her to save money and start building a new house. She will use the loan to purchase more shoes to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to finish building her house and then purchase a vehicle.

Samara T. K., 33, is married.  She has two children who are both at school. Samara sells national Kyrgyz drinks (maksym shoro). With the loan, she wants to purchase a variety of shoes and start her own business. In the future she wants to build a house in Bishkek.

Kuljamila A., 61, is a widow.  She has raised four children: three of them are married and live separately with their families. Kuljamila sells shoes at the market; she has been doing this for 30 years. She earns 10,000 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to purchase shoes to increase the turnover of her business. 

Jyrgal B. is the treasurer of the group. She is 40 and divorced. She has a six-year-old daughter. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 15,000 soms, Jyrgal started to sell convenience goods at the market. She earns 20,000 soms per month. With the loan, she wants to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she plans to start repairing her flat. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase shoes

loans.name: Bagdat

texts.ru:
Bagdat G. 45 let. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey  sin kotoromu 16 let i doch kotoroy 10 let. Eqo sin uchitsya v shkole  i zanimayestya sportom i dochka toje uchitsya v shkole v to je vremya zanimayestya tancami.  On i eqo semya jivut v Fuzuli regione. 

Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoeqo starsheqo brata i potom reshil sebe otrik maqazin . On uje 7 let rabotayet v etom maqazine . Seychas on nujdayetsya 2000 AZN chtobi kupit produkti dlya pereprodaji . V budushem on xotelbi uvelichit pomesheniye svoeqo maqazina.
texts.en:
Bagdat G. is 45 years old. He is married and has two children, a 16-year-old son and 10-year-old daughter. His son studies in school and engages in sports, and his daughter also is in school and studies dance in her free time. He and his family live in the Fuzuli region. He started his business with his older brother and then decided to open his own shop. On has been working in this store for seven years. Now he needs a loan in order to purchase products for resale. In the future, he wishes to expand the offerings in his store.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi B. is married and has five dependants. She has been through junior high school. Esi operates a food joint where she prepares fufu with various types of soups to sell at Takoradi. Her husband is a train driver.  Esi uses her income to help her husband pay utility bills.  Esi will use the loan to purchase more and different foodstuffs to cook to bring variety into her foods. With the new profits from her expanded business, Esi plans to save to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loans.use: To purchase more and different foodstuffs to cook

loans.name: Izatoy

texts.en:
A. Izatoy is a married woman with 3 children. She started her business as the result of economic pressure: her husband's salary was not enough to meet their family expenses. Izatoy began to investigate what work she could do. About 10 years ago, one of her friends recommended that she sell women’s footwear. She decided to try that business. Little by little she brought in more clients, which increased her income as she sold more goods. Izatoy is applying for a loan of 6,000 Somoni to buy merchandise and to fill existing client orders. She hopes that you will collaborate with her. Together with her family, Izatoy thanks you for supporting them and helping the family to move ahead.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to increasing the working capital

loans.name: Badenya Ton 3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Badenya Ton 3 est constitué de huit mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, avec en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et habitant toutes le village de Farabougou dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture et diversifier les spéculations, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver de l’arachide, du mil et du sésame.
Connue pour sa grande productivité d’arachide, Madame Djouma D. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 50kg de semence d’arachide, 3 sacs de complexe céréales et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de sarclage et de récolte d’arachide dans son champ. 
Elle se ravitaille en semence à la foire de Gouassola et en main d’œuvre avec les hommes du village. 
Elle compte récolter sur une superficie de 3,2 hectares: 30 sacs d’arachide et 4 sacs de mil. Le mil et une partie de la production d’arachide rentre dans la consommation familiale tandis que le reste est vendu à la foire de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les frais scolaires des enfants et les dépenses du foyer au quotidien. 
Madame Djouma   D. a pour ambition l’achat des matériels agricoles qui pourra amoindrir les charges d’exploitation de ses champs dans le futur.
texts.en:
The Badenya Ton 3 group is made up of eight married women, most of whom live in large traditional families. They have an average age of 38 years and an average of 4 children and all live in the village of Farabougou in the rural commune of Tesserla in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other through marriage, kinship, and neighborly ties. In order to increase their crop size and diversify the kinds of crops grown, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first seasonal loan. The group members will grow peanuts, millet, and sesame. Known for her impressive peanut production, Mrs. Djouma D. plans on using the loan to buy 50 kg of peanut seeds and 3 sacks of grains, and to pay for workers to weed and harvest the peanuts. She buys seeds at the market in Gouassola and she employs men from her village to work in the fields. On 3.2 hectares of land, she plans to harvest: 30 sacks of peanuts and 4 sacks of millet. The millet and a portion of the peanuts will be kept for the group's families, while the rest will be sold at the Ségou market to a mixed client base. The profits will be used to take care of children's schooling costs as well as household expenses. Mrs. Djouma D.'s goal is to buy agricultural materials that will be able to lessen the expenses incurred from working her fields.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pay workers

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame A. is married and taking care of four children. She is into the sale of charcoal and secondhand clothes. She has been educated up to the senior high level. Her husband is a driver.  Maame uses her earnings to support her husband in paying school fees and utility bills.  Maame will use the loan to buy charcoal and bales of secondhand clothes to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to save to rent a shop at the market place to be able to sell in larger quantities.

loans.use: To buy charcoal and bales of secondhand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena S. sells a variety of smoked fish at Takoradi. She has been educated up to the senior high school level. She is divorced and has six dependents. She is responsible for taking care of her dependents.

Abena has been selling smoked fish for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy more fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to use the new revenues from her business to plough back into her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida P. is from the town of Talibon. She is 39 years old. Zenaida is married and has 5 school-aged children. Zenaida owns & operates a fishing business, gathering and selling seaweeds at the market. Her husband is also a fisherman. She helps him sell all his catch at the market.

Zenaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Badenya Ton  4 Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes  du groupe Badenya Ton 4 sont mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, avec en moyenne 39 ans, 5 enfants et habitant le village de Farabougou dans la commune rurale de Tesserela dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de voisinage. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture et diversifier les spéculations, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver de l’arachide, du mil, du pois de terre et du sésame.
Madame Nièdiogou  Sangaré veut utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semence d’arachide, 15kg de mil comme semence, un sac de complexe céréales et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en semences à la foire de Ségou et en main d’œuvre avec les hommes et les femmes du village. 
Elle compte récolter sur une superficie de  3 hectares: 15 sacs d’arachide, 5 sacs de mil et 3 sacs de sésame. Le mil et une partie de la production d’arachide sont utilisés dans la consommation familiale tandis que le reste est vendu à la foire de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge les frais scolaires, de santé des enfants et les dépenses du foyer au jour le jour. 
Madame Nièdiogou  Sangaré tout comme les autres membres du groupe a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire et l’élevage des petits ruminants dans le village.
texts.en:
The eight women of the Badenya Ton 4 group are married and live in large traditional families, averaging 39 years of age and 5 children each, and they live in the village of Farabougou in the rural commune of Tesserela in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other through marriage, kinship, and neighborly ties. In order to increase their amount of arable land and diversify their crops, they have turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first seasonal loan. The group members will grow peanuts, millet, peas, and sesame. Mrs. Nièdiogou Sangaré wants to use the loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds, 15 kg of millet seeds, 1 sac of grain, and to pay for workers to work in the fields. She buys seeds at the Ségou market and she employs men and women from her village to work in the fields. In a 3 hectare area, she plans on harvesting 15 sacks of peanuts, 5 sacks of millet, and 3 sacks of sesame. THe millet and a portion of the peanuts will be kept for their families, while the rest will be sold at the Ségou market to a mixed client base. The profits will be used to pay for schooling costs, medical care of their children, and daily household expenses. Mrs. Nièdiogou Sangaré, like the other group members, wants to ensure that her family is self-sufficient with regards to food, and wants to raise small ruminant animals in the village.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and seeds, and pay workers

loans.name: Mahmud

texts.en:
