la sra. Reina Isabel M. G. se dedica al comercio, vende productos lácteos desde hace mas de 1 año. su negocio esta ubicado en su casa de habitación, sus ventas las realiza al por menor y mayor.
Generalmente los días sábados de cada semana es el dia de mayor venta, el producto lácteo lo compra a los vendedores que vienen de las ganaderías que se ubican en ese sector lo que le genera mayor rentabilidad.
    
El credito lo utilizara para la compra de mas producto ya que no cuenta con el capital suficiente para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.  



la sra Dilcia Marina N. R. se dedica al comercio, cuenta con una pulpería y venta de helados (conos y ice creams) ubicada en su casa de habitación en el Barrio El Jazmín del municipio de Las Trojes desde hace mas de 8 años.
En cuanto a la venta de conos su esposo también los distribuye de forma ambulante en los diferentes barrios y colonias y aldeas cercanas al municipio y de esta forma La Sra. Dilcia N. y su esposo se  apoyan mutuamente para satisfacer las obligaciones familiares y cumplir con los compromisos que tienen.

el credito lo utilizara para comprar mercaderia para su pulperia.


la Sra. Iris Jackeline H. se dedica a elaboración y venta de tortillas, actividad que tiene más de 3 años de realizar, la mayor parte del producto que ella vende es por contrato lo que le permite tener clientes todo el año y de esta forma contribuye a su esposo con los gastos del hogar , su esposo se dedica a la albañilería, con los ingresos que obtienen de estas actividades se apoyan mutuamente.    
el credito lo utilizara para comprar leña, maiz, cal y agua.
texts.en:
The El Puente (The Bridge) Group is composed of 4 very hard-working women with much desire to advance their businesses and their families. Details concerning their different activities follow: Gloria sells sweets from her store, located in her home. She has done this for more than 2 years. The business generates income and she has a very reliable clientèle, since she is at a strategic location, on one of the most frequented routes of the municipality of Las Trojes. Gloria is the mother of 2 school-age children who study at the local primary school. Her husband raises cattle and the zone is very apt for that activity. In this form, they mutually contribute to the home. Gloria's loan will be used to buy primary materials to make her sweets and thus, to satisfy client demands. Reina is a merchant, selling milk products for more than a year from her store, located in her home. She sells both wholesale and retail. Generally, Saturdays are the best day for sales. She buys her milk products from vendors who come from dairies in this sector that will generate her greatest profits. Reina's loan will be used to buy more products, since she lacks sufficient capital to satisfy customer demand. Her loan will be used to buy merchandise for her general store. Dilcia is a merchant with a general store that sells ice cream (in cones), located in her home in Barrio El Jazmín, municipality of Las Trojes, for more than 8 years. Concerning selling ice cream cones, her husband also distributes them on foot in different neighborhoods and towns around the municipality in this form. Dilcia and her husband help each other in order to satisfy family obligations and comply with their obligations. Iris makes and sells tortillas, and has done this for more than 3 years. The majority of her production is by contract, which permits her to have clients year-round. In this manner, she contributes, along with her husband, to household expenses. Her husband is a bricklayer. With the income they earn through these activities they mutually contribute. Iris' loan will be utilized to buy firewood, corn, lime, and water.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MILK PRODUCTS, GROCERIES, INCLUDING MEAT AND VEGETABLES, AND BASIC NECESSETIES TO MAKE AND SELL GOODS SUCH AS SWEETS AND TORTILLAS

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.es:
Rogelio reside en cantón corralito Corinto departamento de Morazán, es casado vive con su esposa Ana María y cinco hijos los mayores de los hijos estudian,
cuenta que desde que era pequeño su papa le enseño a trabajar en el campo en la producción de granos básicos como maíz, frijol, maicillo entre otros cuenta Rogelio que es un trabajo muy pesado por que se levanta a las cuatro de la mañana y sale a las cuatro de la tarde.
el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de abono, semilla y fertilizantes ya que sin ellos el maíz no crese y no sería una buena producción.
esto le ayudara a mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus hijos y su esposa ya que la situación económica esta muy difícil.
sus aspiraciones es tener una buena producción y de esta forma poder darle asu familia un mejor futuro con buenas condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Rogelio lives in the Corralito, Corinto canton, Morazán department. He is married and lives with his wife Ana María and five children. The older children are in school. He told us that when he was a boy his father taught him how to work the land to produce basic grains such as corn, beans, millet and others. He said the work is difficult because he must rise at four in the morning and work until four in the afternoon. He will invest this loan in the purchase of fertilizer and seed. Without the addition of nutrients to the soil, the corn does not grow and the harvest would be small. A good harvest will improve the living conditions of his children and his wife; the economic situation is now very difficult. His wish is to have a good harvest and thereby give his family a better future with a higher standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer and seed.

loans.name: Jose Nelson

texts.es:
Nelson reside en Cantón la laguna Corinto departamento de Morazán, vive con María su esposa y sus cuatro hijos los dos hijos mayores estudian, los cuatro hijos dependen de los ingresos que obtiene.
Desde su niñez comenzó a trabajar en la siembra de granos y ganado gracias a que su papa se lo inculco porque él se dedica a trabajar en el campo.
El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de insumos agrícolas  ganados y cerdos para crecerlos y comercializarlos en el tiangue municipal de Corinto.
Le ayudara a una mejor producción de maíz y ganado y de esta forma  poder genera ingresos para las necesidades básicas del hogar. 
Sus sueños es tener una buena producción de maíz ganado y cerdos para poder mejorar las condiciones de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Nelson lives in La Laguna Corinto canton, Marazón department. He lives with María, his wife, and their four children. The two older children are in school. The four children depend on Nelson's income. When he was a boy, he began to work sowing grains and raising cattle. He is grateful to his father for teaching him this work. This loan will be invested in agricultural products such as fertilizer, cattle, and pigs. He will raise the animals and sell them in the Corinto city market. This investment will improve his production of corn and cattle and thereby generate income for basic household necessities. His dream is to have a good production of corn, cattle, and pigs to improve the standard of living of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Jeff Schell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of agricultural products such as fertilizer, cattle, and pigs

loans.name: El Triunfo 3 Group

texts.es:
el grupo El Triunfo 3 esta ubicado en el Barrio la Libertad de la Comunidad de EL Triunfo, Choluteca. esta integrado por 3 mujeres muy trabajadoras y con muchas ganas de salir adelante. a continuacion se detallan las diferentes actividades que ellas realizan para ganarse la vida diariamente:

la sra Ada Teresa H. se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia desde hace varios años, Teresa es madre de 4 hijos los cuales los tiene estudiando en la escuela de la comunidad
doña Teresa se levanta a las 4 de la mañana para atender a su clientela ya que vive en una zona bien productiva, Teresa y su esposo trabajan duro para sacar adelante a su familia, en sus tiempos libres lo dedica  para asistir a la  iglesia y criar gallinas.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas mercaderia y asi surtir su pulperia.

la joven Vanyi M. se dedica a la fabricacion de coronas y piñatas desde hace 5 años, esto lo aprendio junto a su madre que tambien le ayuda con la fabricacion de las piñatas, Vanyi se acaba de casar y con la ayuda de su esposo estan trabajando duro para comprarse una vivienda ya que viven con su madre, en su tiempo libre  se dedica  al estudio ya que tambien estudia en la universidad.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas materiales para fabricar las coronas y las piñatas.


la joven Elsania A. es una joven emprendedora que se dedica al negocio propio venta de refrescos y 
 charamuscas en su casa de habitacion, Elsania vive con su madre que tambien le ayuda a la venta.
Elsania se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para hacer su producto y tenerlo listo para el resto del dia, el dia que mas vende son los domingos.

su tiempos libres lo dedica a la iglesia.
el prestamo lo utilizara para comprar mas refrescos y materiales para la fabricacion de las charamuscas.
texts.en:
The 'El Triunfo 3' group is located in the La Libertad neighbourhood of the El Triunfo community, Choluteca. Its members are three very hard-working women who really want to succeed. The different activities they are involved in to earn a living are described below: Ada Teresa H. sells everyday consumer goods and has been running her grocery shop for several years. Teresa is a mother of 4 children who all go to the local school. Teresa gets up at 4am to serve her customers, as the area she lives in is very productive. Teresa and her husband work hard to provide for their family. In her spare time, she goes to church and breeds chickens. She will use the loan to buy more stock for her grocery business. Young Vanyi M. has been making garlands and piñatas for 5 years. She learned the skill from her mother, who now helps her to make the piñatas. Vanyi has just got married and together she and her husband are working hard to buy their own home, as they currently live with her mother. In her spare time, she studies because she also attends university. She will use the loan to buy more materials with which to make her garlands and piñatas. Elsania A. is a young entrepreneur who has her own business selling soft drinks and twisted candy from her home. Elsania lives with her mother, who helps herto sell her products. Elsania gets up at 5am to make her produce and get it ready for the rest of the day. She sells the most on Sundays. She goes to church in her spare time. She will use her loan to buy soft drinks and materials for making her twisted candy.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Stansfield, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans, rice, sugar, corn, tortillas, flour, butter, oil, cereal, soft drinks, paper, coloured paper, glue, pumps, paper decorations, colours, bookmarks, artificial flowers, plastic bags, fruit,  artificial flavourings.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesus

texts.es:
Teresa resiD. en barrio las delicias Corinto Departamento D. Morazán, vive con su esposo y un hijo D. la edad D. 21 años el cual le ayuda en la panadería.
Aprendió hacer pan gracias a su mama que elaboraba artesanalmente el pan, ella residía en santa rosa Departamento D. Morazán y decidió mudarse a Corinto para mejorar su negocio ya que en el lugar donD. ella residía no era mucho la demanda al contrario en Corinto tiene mejores oportunidades para que su negocio pueda crecer.
El crédito lo invertirá en compra D. harina azúcar levadura y también comprara una bicicleta para salir a vender el pan por la residencia.
D. esta forma ella comercializara mejor el producto y los ingresos serán una buena oportunidad para mejorar su condición D. vida ya que la demanda es buena en la zona.
sus aspiraciones es ampliar su negocio y poder ser una vendedora D. mayoreo a las tiendas y los negocios más grandes y D. esta forma mejorar las condiciones D. vida en la educación y la salud D. su familia.
texts.en:
Teresa lives in Corinto’s Delicias neighborhood, Morazán department, with her husband and a 21-year-old son who helps out in the bakery. She learned how to bake bread from her mother who was an artisanal bread maker. She lived in Santa Rosa, Morazán department but decided to move to Corinto to improve her business because where she used to live there was little demand for her products whereas in Corinto she has more opportunities for her business to grow. She will use the funds to buy flour, sugar and yeast and also to buy a bicycle to use to go out and sell the bread throughout the neighborhood. This way she will be able to sell her product better and income will be a good opportunity for her to improve her standard of living because demand is good in this area. Her dreams are to expand her business and be able to become a wholesaler in stores and large firms so that her living conditions will improve especially with respect to her family’s education and health.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy flour, sugar, yeast.

loans.name: Rosa Isabel

texts.es:
Rosa Isabel U. tiene la edad de 54 años, es soltera y madre de 4 hijos, los cuales todos ya están casados y ninguno bajo su cargo.
Doña Rosa se dedica al comercio desde hace 20 años en el mercado municipal y hasta la fecha permanece con su negocio.
Ceprodel le ha otorgado seis créditos los cuales han sido para invertir en su negocio y hasta hace muy poco ella se dedicaba solamente a la venta de gaseosas, ya que decidió invertir también en abarroterías lo cual le ha permitido incrementar sus ventas.
Cabe mencionar que doña Rosa ha sido muy responsable con sus créditos y esto le ha permitido mantener un buen record crediticio.
texts.en:
Rosa Isabel U. is 54 years old, she is single and mother of 4 children, who are all already married and not in her care. Rosa has been in business for 20 years at the municipal market and has remained with her business to date. Ceprodel has granted her six loans which have been for investment in her business and until very recently she only sold sodas, then she decided to also invest groceries which has led to an increase in sales. It is worth mentioning that Rosa has been very responsible with her loans and this has enabled her keep a good credit record.

Translated from Spanish by Catherine Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, soap, oil, cookies, different flavors of coca cola, juices)

loans.name: Luvy María

texts.es:
Doña Luvy María B. L. tiene la edad de 48 años, es casada y con 4 hijos de los cuales solamente 3 están bajo su cargo. Su esposo se dedica a ayudarle a doña Luvy en lo que es el acarreo de la leche, ya que tienen que irla a traer a otra comunidad que queda a 5 km de distancia.
Doña Luvy habita en Malpaisillo en una comunidad llamada calle real de tolapa pero se dedica a la venta de cuajada en el mercado municipal de Chichigalpa desde hace 12 años, viaja todos los días con su negocio de cuajada y crema y nos comentaba que ha sido un buen punto de venta, ya que ha hecho clientela y además su cuajada es reconocida como de calidad.
Los 27 créditos que Ceprodel le ha facilitado han sido para su negocio y este ultimo que solicito fue para ajustar y comprar una camioneta la cual ellos utilizaran para transportar la leche, ya que la que actualmente tiene es muy baja y no es la indicada para el terreno en que ellos se mueven para el transporte de la leche.
texts.en:
Luvy María B. L. is 48 years old and married. She has four children, but only three of them are under her care. Her husband devotes himself to helping Luvy transport the milk. They have to take it to another community, which is five kilometers away. Luvy lives in Malpaisillo in a community called Calle Real de Tolapa. But, she has been selling curd in the Chichigalpa municipal market for 12 years. She travels everyday with her curd and cream business. She tells us that it has been a good spot for sales. This is because she has gotten customers, and because her curd is recognized as being of quality. The 27 loans that Ceprodel has facilitated have been for her business. This last one that she requested was to buy and fix a truck. They will use the truck to transport the milk. The one that they currently have is very low, and it is not for use on the terrain they use to transport the milk.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a truck to transport milk

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa A. is divorced and taking care of four children. She has received junior high education.  Yaa sells salt, plantains, garden eggs and other foodstuffs at Takoradi. Yaa uses her returns from her sales to educate, feed and clothe her children. Yaa says the loan will be of great help to her. She will use the loan to buy other varieties of foodstuffs to supply to her demanding customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Yaa plans to save to build a shop to sell her goods in.

loans.use: buy other varieties of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A. sells fruit, bags of water, and other items at Takoradi. She has been educated up to the senior high level. She is divorced and living with her four children. Nana uses her income to pay school fees and utility bills.  Nana will use the loan to purchase other types of fruit to bring variety into her inventory. With the new profits from her extended business, Nana plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase other types of fruits to bring variety into her inventory

loans.name: Mena

texts.en:
Mena E. is married and has two children. She has not received any form of education. Mena sells cassava and plantains at Takoradi. Most people use this combination for 'fufu' (a staple of the diet). Some also cook the plantains and eat them as lunch with any kind of sauce. Likewise cassava can also be eaten as lunch. 

Mena's husband is a mason.  Mena uses her earnings to help her husband with the general upkeep of the home. Mena will use the loan to purchase more foodstuffs for sale. With the new revenue from her expanded business, Mena plans to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Martha

texts.en: Martha Q. sells foodstuffs at Takoradi.  Martha has attained senior high level of education.  She is married to a driver and has four children with him. She responsibly helps her husband in taking care of her children. Her loan will be used to buy additional foodstuffs for sale. She hopes to reinvest into her business, should there be any increase in her income.

loans.use: buy additional foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama T. cooks rice at Takoradi for sale.  Ama has not received any form of education.  She is married and taking care of five dependents. Her husband works with Zoom Lion Company. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy a bag of rice and other ingredients to prepare her sauce for sale. She hopes to reinvest her profit back into her business.

loans.use: buy a bag of rice and other ingredients to prepare her sauce for sale

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma M. sells yogurt and other ice creams at Takoradi. Emma has received senior high education.  She is married and has one child. Her husband is a driver.

Emma has been selling yogurt for some time now. She responsibly helps her husband in providing the basic needs of her child. Her loan will be used to buy more yogurt and other ice creams for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to expand her business.

loans.use: buy more yogurt and other ice creams for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame E. trades in vegetables and foodstuffs at Takoradi.  Maame has been through junior high school. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a painter. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy extra food items for sale. She hopes to plough back her profit into her business.

loans.use: buy extra food items for sale

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa N. is a charcoal seller in Takoradi. She is a married woman living with her five dependents. She has not received any formal education. Her husband is a palm wine tapper.  

Adwoa uses her returns from her sales to help her husband in providing the basic needs of her family.  Adwoa will use the loan to purchase additional bags of charcoal to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adwoa plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: purchase additional bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Mena

texts.en: Mena A. sells fried fish at Takoradi. She is married and has three children. She has received senior high education.  Mena’s husband is a stores officer.  Mena uses her income to help her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Mena will use the loan to purchase extra fresh fish to fry to sell. With the fresh profits from her extended business, Mena plans to save to build a shop to sell in.

loans.use: purchase extra fresh fish to fry for sale

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua Y. is divorced and has three children. She sells plantains, cassava, palm fruits, and bagged charcoal at Takoradi. Efua uses her income to educate and feed her children. Efua will add the money to her initial capital to buy other foodstuffs for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save to invest in her children’s education.

loans.use: buy other varieties of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba S. is a widow and has five dependents. She has received senior high education. Araba sells foodstuffs at Takoradi. She takes care of her family with the income she makes from her sales.  She will use the loan to purchase extra food items for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to buy a plot of land.

loans.use: purchase extra food items for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame M. is married and has four children. She has no educational background.  Maame operates a provisions shop at Takoradi. With the help of her husband she is able to take good care of her children. Maame will add the loan to her original money to purchase more provisions that consumers have been requesting.  She anticipates using the new revenue she is hopeful of generating to open another shop at a different locality.

loans.use: purchase more provisions that consumers have been requesting

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame K. is married.  She has senior high educational background.  Maame sells cooked rice and serves it with palm-nut soup at Takoradi. Her husband is a driver.  Maame adds her income to that of her husband to take care of the entire household. She will use the loan to purchase more rice to cook and to add other foods to it for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to open a shop where she can sell different varieties of cooked foods.

loans.use: purchase more rice to cook and add other foods to it for sale

loans.name: Sister

texts.en: Sister N. is married and has four children. She has received senior high education.  Sister sells second-hand ladies' underwear at Takoradi. Her husband is a saw miller.  Sister uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Sister will use the loan to purchase a bale of second-hand underwear for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sister plans to save to invest in her children’s education.

loans.use: purchase a bale of second-hand underwear for sale

loans.name: Alice

texts.en: Alice A. sells provisions at Takoradi.  Alice has received junior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a driver. Alice has been selling provisions for some time now. She helps her husband in providing the basic needs of her family. Her loan will be used to buy additional varieties of provisions for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to open another shop in a different locality.

loans.use: to buy additional varieties of provisions for sale

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice C. sells canned tomatoes, raw rice, cooking oil and other items at Takoradi.  Beatrice has received junior high education.  She is married to a security man and living with her six dependents. She responsibly helps her husband in the the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more of her goods to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: buy more of her goods to sell

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame N. is married and has three children. She sells cloth, ladies' shoes and slippers by moving from one area to another at Takoradi. Maame has no educational background. Her husband is a farmer.  Maame uses her income to help her husband in educating her children.  Maame will use the loan to purchase more goods to expand her business. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to save to buy a shop.

loans.use: purchase more goods to expand her business

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa K. sells snacks with soft drinks at Takoradi. She is married but has no child yet. She has not received any formal education. Her husband is a mason.  Adwoa uses her income to help her husband support the household.  

Adwoa will use the loan to purchase more goods to bring variety into her sales and to meet the demand of customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Adwoa plans to save to build a shop for her business.

loans.use: purchase more goods to being variety into her inventory

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther O. works as a hairdresser and also sells biscuits, toffees, bread, oranges and other items at Takoradi.  Esther has received senior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a tailor. 

Esther has been selling biscuits and other items for some time now. She responsibly helps her husband in the upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to further expand her business.

loans.use: buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Jemima

texts.en: Jemima H. is a single parent taking care of two children. She has received junior high education.  Jemima sells bags of charcoal at Takoradi. Jemima uses her income to take care of her children.  Jemima will use the loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to distribute to her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Jemima plans to save to put up a structure to keep her charcoal out of the weather.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal to distribute to her customers.

loans.name: Efua Maame

texts.en:
Efua Maame Y. sells rice, gari (a couscous-like grain made from grated cassava), bread, margarine, sugar and other items at Takoradi. Her loan will be used to buy more goods to fill her shop. She hopes to use the new revenues from her business to save to educate her children.

Efua Maame has attained junior high level of education. She is married to an electrician and has three children. She is responsible by supporting her husband in taking care of her family.

loans.use: To buy more goods to fill her shop

loans.name: Sister

texts.en:
Sister A. sells cloth at Takoradi and has been in this trade for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy extra cloth to sell. She hopes to use the new earnings from her business to reinvest in her business.

Sister has been through senior high school. She is married to a sand winner (a person that excavates sand) and has three children. She responsibly supports her husband in providing the basic needs of her family.

loans.use: To buy extra cloth to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth D. is married to an electrician and has three children. She has received senior high education.

Elizabeth sells soft drinks at Takoradi and uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase additional soft drinks to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce E. produces locally-made soap for sale at Takoradi. Her loan will be used to buy extra ingredients to prepare soap for sale. She hopes to reinvest in her business the new profit she anticipates earning from her sales.

Joyce has been educated up to junior high school level. She is married to a secondhand-clothes seller and has three children. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy extra ingredients to prepare more soap for sale

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Maame A. sells provisions at Takoradi and has been in this trade for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy additional provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children.

Maame has received junior high education. She is married to a steel binder and has four children. She helps her husband to take care of the entire family.

loans.use: To buy additional provisions to sell

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Juliana B. has been selling bags of charcoal and firewood at Takoradi for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy extra bags of charcoal to sell. She plans on saving towards buying a piece of land.

Juliana has attained a senior high school level of education. She is married and has five dependents. She responsibly helps her husband in feeding and educating her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy E. is single and has received junior high school education. She sells jewelry and ladies’ wear at Takoradi and uses her income to pay her utility bills.

Lucy will use the loan she hopes to receive to purchase more panties and jeans to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to buy a shop.

loans.use: To purchase more panties and jeans to sell

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce has acquired senior high education. She is married to a builder and has one child. With the support of her husband, she is able to provide for the needs of her family.

Joyce T. has been selling wax print cloth and provisions at Takoradi for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards her child’s further education.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah L. sells cosmetics by moving from one area to another at Takoradi. Her loan will be used to buy more cosmetics to sell. She hopes to build a shop for her business, should there be any form of increase in her sales.

Sarah has received senior high education. She is married to a mason and lives with him and their two children. She is responsible by supporting her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua K. is married to a farmer and has five dependents. She has no educational background.

Ekua sells charcoal at Takoradi both in small and larger quantities. She uses the income from her sales to support her husband in providing the basic needs of her family such as feeding, clothing and educating her children.

Ekua will use the loan to acquire additional bags of charcoal to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. is divorced and taking care of one child. She has not received any form of education.  Efua sells foodstuffs such as garden eggs (small eggplants), tomatoes, salted fish and the like at Takoradi. Efua uses her income in insuring the well-being of her family.

Efua will use the loan to purchase more foodstuffs for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save to acquire a shop she could display her goods in.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Ama Maame

texts.en: Ama Maame P. operates a provisions shop at Takoradi. Ama Maame has received junior high education.  She is divorced with a child. She has been in this trade for some time now. She is responsible for providing a better life for herself and her child. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions to meet the demand of her customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: buy more provisions to meet the demand of her customers

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Veronica E. is married and has one child. She has been through senior high school. Veronica sells groceries at Takoradi. Her husband is a cook. Veronica uses her income in helping her husband take care of her family. Veronica will use the loan to purchase more groceries for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Veronica plans to reinvest her returns.

loans.use: purchase more groceries for sale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa B. is married to a driver and has three children. She has received senior high education.  Yaa sells second-hand clothes at Takoradi. Yaa uses her income to help her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.  Yaa will use the loan to purchase extra bales of second-hand clothes for sale. With the new profits from her extended business, Yaa plans to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: purchase extra bales of second-hand clothes for resale

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua E. sells cassava and plantains at Takoradi.  Efua has been through junior high school.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a sand and stone contractor. She helps her husband in the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to further her children's education.

loans.use: buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua E. sells cooking utensils at Takoradi. Ekua has received senior high education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a mason. Ekua has been selling cooking utensils for some time now. She responsibly helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more utensils for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children.

loans.use: buy more utensils for sale

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta B. smokes fish at Takoradi for sale. Atta has been through senior high school.  She is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a mason. 

Atta has been selling smoked fish for some time now. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to educate her children.

loans.use: buy more fresh fish to smoke for sale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther N. sells fresh and frozen fish and meat at Takoradi.  Esther has junior high educational background.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a miner. 

Esther has been selling fresh fish and meat for some time now. She helps her husband with the general upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more fresh fish for sale. She hopes to plough back her profit into her business.

loans.use: buy more fresh fish for sale

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba N. operates a food joint where she prepares 'fufu' for sale at Takoradi.  Araba has a little foundation in formal education. She is divorced and taking care of four children. She responsibly and single-handedly takes care of her four dependents. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs to cook since customers have started requesting other kinds of food. She anticipates using the new profits from her business to save to further her children’s education.

loans.use: buy more foodstuffs to cook

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa K. sells cooked rice at Takoradi. Adwoa has received senior high education.  She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. She helps her husband in providing for the general welfare of the home. Her loan, she says, will enable her to buy and cook food in larger quantities to sell. She hopes to reinvest her profit into her business.

loans.use: buy and cook food in larger quantities for resale

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is an entrepreneur from Novaya Kahovka. She sells children’s clothing merchandise at two vending locations in local stores. Yelena has been in this business for 11 years. Presently, she has 50,000 Grivnyas in turnover capital. Her net profit amounts to 8,000 Grivnyas. 

Yelena is a determined entrepreneur. She knows how to set goals and achieve them. This time, Yelena is seeking a loan of 15,000 Grivnyas to diversify into assorted merchandise and boost her sales as a result. She believes that financial assistance in combination with her zeal, perseverance and diligent work will help her consistently expand and grow her business.

loans.use: To diversify assorted merchandise

loans.name: Ivanna

texts.en:
Ivanna is married with a 13-year-old son, Andryi. She is a market entrepreneur from Stryi, Western Ukraine. Ivanna sells sports gear in small town markets in the Stryi Region. She offers a nice selection of clothing items at affordable prices. Ivanna has been in business for 14 years. Her gross income is 25,000 UAH a month. Her net profit is 3,000 UAH a month.

Ivanna is seeking a loan of 10,000 UAH in order to increase her turnover capital and sales as a result. The loan will give her business a good economic boost and will help her meet the high demand for her products this season.

loans.use: To increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Ilseyar

texts.en:
Ilseyar is married with two children: a 12-year-old son and a 6-year-old daughter. She sells retail items (i.e., camera accessories, office and school supplies) in one of the local marketplaces in her hometown of Kahovka. Ilseyar has been in this business for 11 years. Presently, she has 16,000 UAH invested in inventory. Her net profit is about 6,000 UAH a month.   

Ilseyar is requesting a loan of 12,000 UAH to use as working capital to buy necessary inventory and increase assorted merchandise. With her history thus far as an entrepreneur, it will be exciting to watch how her business will grow and prosper in the future.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy hairdryers and lotion

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence is 60 years old and is married with seven children aged between 9 to 40 years. He has no other dependents. He lives in his own home with his family in Hoima, Uganda. His family goal is to educate his children.

Lawrence has been in the textile business for forty years. He started by being a tailor and then saved money and started his own business. He has no major hardships in his business and in future he wants to start a wholesale shop. He wants the loan to purchase clothing material for his business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing material for his business

loans.name: Wilberforce

texts.en:
Wilberforce is a 36-year-old man who wants a loan to purchase sugar, soap, rice, soda and other merchandise to resell in his retail shop. Before starting the retail shop business, he had been into agriculture. He used the proceeds from two seasons to start his retail shop which he has run for the last seven years.

Wilberforce is the father of six children and lives with his family in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He dreams of having a wholesale shop.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, soap, soda and other merchadise for his shop

loans.name: 03.01.24Dien Bien Group

texts.en:
Loan L. T. is a 39 year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Loan is the group leader of a three-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 24.Cho Dien Bien (03.01.24-Dien Bien).

Loan is married and has two school-aged children. To making a living, Loan makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling pork products in the local community. Loan has been engaged in this business for more than 10 years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Loan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Loan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,248,000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,310,000 VND, which will also be used to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the second loan she has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Loan plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:
1.  L. T. Thu is a 30-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her business running a food stall.

2.  P. T. An is a 36-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5,310,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:
The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.



*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.



Loan L. T. (117) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Loan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 3 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 24.Cho Dien Bien (03.01.24-Dien Bien).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ thịt heo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Loan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Loan kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Loan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Loan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.248.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.310.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Thu (118) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


2.  P. T. An (119) là 36 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.310.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Bold

texts.en: Bold Y. is 47 years old and lives with his wife and four-year-old daughter in Huvsgul province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Bold is a very busy man who operates a taxi service in his town. His wife is handicapped, and their daughter goes to a local kindergarten. Bold began his taxi service in 2005. Since then, he has focused solely on managing his transportation business, which has become his family's only source of income. After several successful years in operation, he was able to repair his car with his business earnings. His wife has a health problem and stays at home, so she cannot help her husband. Bold works long hours every day in his business to provide his family with the things they need. He pays for his wife's medical expenses and saves money for his daughter's future tuition fees. He has been trying his best to help his wife overcome her serious illness, but they have not been successful. So Bold is seeking a way to have his wife treated overseas. Until that time comes, though, he will keep working hard in his business and saving money for his family’s future. Bold is requesting a 800,000 MNT loan to purchase some spare parts for his automobile, as well as to purchase a large amount of timber in order to complete his yard.

loans.use: To purchase spare automobile parts

loans.name: Marcosa

texts.en:
Marcosa P., and her husband James P., have six children.  Marcosa and James work hard to cover their daily expenses and put their children through school.  For the past five years Marcosa has been running a Sari-sari or general store in the market, which has provided earnings of 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. 

Marcosa would like to expand her store and increase her inventory, and has applied for a loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase soft drinks, meats, and dried fish.  She hopes the additional goods will allow her to generate more revenue and income.  

Marcosa has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) since 2008 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.  She hopes she will eventually have a prosperous business.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell.

loans.name: Narantsetseg

texts.en:
Narantsetseg Y. is a 51-year-old woman who lives with her husband and grand-daughter in Huvsgul province of western Mongolia. The family lives together in a ger, a traditional nomadic Mongolian tent. Her three children now have their own homes, while her husband helps with her clothes sales business, as well as running a private car repairing service in their town. 

Narantsetseg operates a clothing business which she began in 1993. She has been able to create a strong customer base, having sustained her business successfully for more than 10 years. She is very careful about her clothes design and quality, in order to attract customers' attention. Because of her hard work and good business sense, Narantsetseg has been able to improve her family’s quality of life and hopes that she can eventually help her grand-daughter's education. 

Narantsetseg is a hard working, creative woman who always hopes to improve her business in the future. She is requesting a 1,400,000 Mongolian Tugrik (MNT) loan in order to purchase a large amount of  clothes and uniforms for the upcoming new academic year.

loans.use: To purchase clothes and uniforms to sell.

loans.name: Diosdada

texts.en:
Diosdada P., aged 45, and her husband Eufrocino, aged 50, work hard to cover their daily expenses.  They have a child in college.  For the past ten years Diosada has owned and run a small videoke (karaoke) eatery, which generates 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month in earnings.

Diosdada would like to improve her business and has applied for a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase food (meat, soft drinks, vegetables, and spices) as well as a new microphone for videoke.  She believes the improvements and expanded inventory will help her attract more business and increase earnings.  

Diosdada has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation since 2006 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.  She hopes the earnings from her business will continue to help her cover her basic needs. 

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food business, beverages and a new microphone unit for karaoke.

loans.name: 020806 - Hoang Dong - Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Lan L. T. is a 50-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Dong - Hoang Hoa.  Lan is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 20806 (20806 - hoang dong - hoang hoa).


Lan is married and has four grown-up children.  To making a living, Lan operates a family business raising cattle for sale.  Lan has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 400,000 Vietnamese dong (VND) a month from these activities.


In 2006, Lan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Lan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,749,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.  She is now requesting a new loan of 3,079,800 VND which will be used to purchase more baby livestock to raise and sell.  The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Lan plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her family business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  T. T. Ninh is a 25-year-old woman who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  C. T. Loan is a 55-year-old woman who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


3.  N. T. Chuc is a 55-year-old woman who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  N. T. Ngoc is a 29-year-old woman who is requesting a 3,079,800 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Lan L. T. (208026) là 50 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang dong - Hoang hoa.  Lan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 20806 (20806 - hoang dong - hoang hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Lan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 20 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Lan kiếm được khoảng 400,000 VND.  Vào 2006, Lan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Lan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 30,749,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 3,079,800 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  T. T. Ninh (208046) là 25 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  C. T. Loan (208021) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  N. T. Chuc (208041) là 55 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  N. T. Ngoc (208022) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 3079800 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph D. is from the town of San Pablo. He is 41 years old. Joseph is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Joseph raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) whenever he sells an animal he has raised.

In 2009, Joseph joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the third loan taken out by Joseph from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben G. lives in the village of Sta. Isabel Norte, Ilagan. He is 33 years old, married and has four school-aged children. He makes a living as a farmer, planting and harvesting rice for sale to his customers. He has been a farmer for more than 15  years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per crop.

Earlier this year, Ruben joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is seeking a loan, his first, for 8,000 PHP which will be use to buy additional seeds, seedlings and young plants to raise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated by this loan to continue expanding and improving his farm. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy seeds, seedlings and small plants for a farm

loans.name: Batbaatar

texts.en: Batbaatar N. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own house which was built in 2005. Both of Batbaatar's children attend a district secondary school while his wife helps him out with his business, a retail dairy operation which he runs out of a local market. In the summer, when dairy products are abundant, he buys all of his supplies from Arhangai province, which is known nationally for top-notch products, and resells them from his shop. For the rest of the year, Batbaatar buys dairy products in bulk from Huchit Shonhor, the largest dairy market in Ulaanbaatar. Batbaatar attributes his success to his knowledge of market demands. He is a modest and creative person, and is applying for a loan for 2,500,000 MNT to buy more dairy products to sell during the upcoming winter months when prices for such products rise. He will also use a portion of this loan to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To buy more dairy products to sell to his customers

loans.name: Efren

texts.en:
Efren G. lives in the village of Sta. Isabel Norte, Ilagan. He is 48 years old, married and has one school-aged child. For the last 27 years, he has made a living as a rice farmer, and earns about 40,000 PHP per crop for his work.

Earlier this year, Efren joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for his first loan, for 9,000 PHP, to buy fertilizer. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his farm. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita B. lives in the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 39 years old, married and has four school-aged children. For the last seven years, she has made a living running a general store where customers can buy products they use daily such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. She earns about 4,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2008, Anita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully paid four previous loans from ASKI and is applying for a new one, for 10,000 PHP, to buy more items to sell to her customers.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to improve her family's life.  

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Dialyn

texts.en:
Dialyn P. lives in the village of Turod, Quezon. She is 26 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last two years, she has made a living running a local  convenience store where she sells snacks and candy to people who live in her community.  She earns about 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Dialyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to expand and improve her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn S., age 44, and her husband Nestor, age 44, have three children in school. Nestor works as a security guard and Jocelyn owns an eatery/general store that she has run for the past ten years.  The eatery generates PHP 7,000 a month in earnings for the family and is situated adjacent to their house in Manggahan, Caloocan City.

Jocelyn has applied for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase inventory for her eatery.  She plans on purchasing vegetables, meat, chicken, spices, and soft drinks, in hopes that the additional food will attract customers and increase her revenue.  

Jocelyn has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation since 2006 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.  She hopes to continue to support her family and some day expand her business.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: vegetables, meats, spices and beverages

loans.name: Nieves

texts.en:
Nieves P. is from the village of Lanna, Solana, Cagayan. She is 43 years old. Nieves is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Nieves owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Nieves has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

Nieves joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nieves has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. Nieves is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional animals. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nieves from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase additional animals

loans.name: Byambadorj

texts.en: Byambadorj S. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province, west of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His elder three children attend a local middle school and the youngest child goes to a local kindergarten, while his wife is currently unemployed. Byambadorj has been working as a plumber in his town since 2000. He also works for a local kindergarten as a fireman during the winter season. Byambadorj is a hardworking person who is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a car, by which he would transport people and increase his earnings in order to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To purchase a car

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa B., age 45, and her husband Fernando, age 55, have six children.  They work hard to cover daily expenses and to pay for their children's education.  For the past ten years Teresa has owned and operated her own sari-sari store (general store) which is situated adjacent to her house, to provide additional income for her family.

Teresa has applied for a PHP 14,000 loan to pay for additional groceries for her store, including prepaid phone cards, mineral water, and charcoal.  She hopes that the additional items will attract more customers and allow her to improve her income.  

Teresa has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation since 2008 and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.  She hopes that she will one day expand her business and put all her children through school.

About CCT:

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical missionary work in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

Locally, all CCT community partners and clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: groceries, beverages, sacks of charcoal for retail, firewood and mineral water.

loans.name: Patronila

texts.en:
Patronila G. is from the village of Villa Concepcion Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 50 years old. Patronila is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Patronila owns and operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fruits and vegetables in the community. Patronila is just starting her business.

In 2010, Patronila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Patronila is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Patronila from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen B. is from the village of Brgy. Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 57 years old. Helen is married and has five adult-aged children. To make a living, Helen operates a tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Helen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. loans.name: Nerissa

texts.en:
Our CCT* Community Partner, Nerissa D. L., 41, finished a degree in Midwifery and is married to Emmanuel D. L.. They have three children. They live in Pasay City, south of Manila. Emmanuel works as a train operator. Their three children are all in school: with one in college, another in high school, and the youngest in elementary.

Nerissa finished midwifery but chose to do a business related to transportation. They presently own vehicles which are for hire, mainly by companies. Nerissa also has a small business in rag-making. Altogether, the net earnings of the family per month amount to P11,960. 

Nerissa is applying for a loan of P12,000, which she plans to use to register two of her vehicles to be officially used in business. She would also use the loan to improve the conditions of the vehicles by changing the color and adding some accessories.

At present, Nerissa finds the daily collections from the business difficult. Sometimes, the vehicles are penalized for violation, which adds up expenses. At times, the vehicles get damaged and need repairs. However, Nerissa still hopes and believes that God has destined her for a greater purpose. She dreams to own a bigger business with more vehicles that would cater to many more companies in Metro Manila and beyond. She also hopes that her rag-making business will increase in sales. She aims for these breakthroughs in business because, at the bottom line, she aspires to buy her family their own house and lot.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Towards vehicle registration and maintenance.

loans.name: Ma. Evelina

texts.en:
Ma. Evelina’s desire to give her daughter a brighter future fuels her commitment to her business. She is a very hard-working woman, firm to achieve a better life. Despite the challenges and hardships caused by poverty, Ma. Evelina is still strong and dedicated in her mission to improve her family’s standard of living. The love and care of her husband makes her life quite meaningful.

To earn a living, Ma. Evelina makes “pawid “(can be used for house roofs) out of coconut leaves. Like others, they use it since they can’t afford to buy the galvanize iron for roofing. She has been engaged in this business for four years. She joined ASHI in 2007, a microfinance institution and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During the course of her membership, she has been an excellent performer with respect to regular attendance at center and group meetings, loan repayment, and projects. She is now seeking her third loan for the amount of 13,000 PHP to purchase raw materials needed for her business.

With access to additional working funds through Kiva supporters, Ma. Evelina is optimistic that her dreams of sending her only daughter to a university, to complete college degrees, will be achieved and they will have a happy family in a simple way of living.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed for her business.

loans.name: 060117-Hoang Chau-Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en: Thao N. T. (83) is a 56-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa. Thao is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 060117 - Hoang Chau - Hoang Hoa (060117 - hoang chau - hoang hoa). Thao is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Thao operates a family member's fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling farm-raised fish in the local community. Thao has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 3,079,800 Vietnamese Dong (VND) a month from it. Thao joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thao has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to raise. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will also be used to purchase additional fish to raise. This will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thao plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. L. T. Nha (81) is a 42-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business. 2. T. T. Thiet (41) is a 58-year-old woman who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business. 3. C. T. Dan (110) is a 44-year-old woman who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business of making and selling food. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Thao N. T. (83) là 56 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa. Thao là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 060117 - hoang chau - hoang hoa (060117 - hoang chau - hoang hoa). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ thu hoạch & bán các loại cá nuôi tại nông trại trong cộng đồng địa phương. Thao thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Thao kiếm được khoảng 3,079,800 VND. Thao đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Thao đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua cá bổ sung để nuôi. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. L. T. Nha (81) là 42 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản. 2. T. T. Thiet (41) là 58 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản. 3. C. T. Dan (110) là 44 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là sản xuất & buôn bán thức ăn. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."
