loans.name: Necitas

texts.en:
Having attained a college education, Necitas C., 37, wants to achieve more in life, not just for herself but for her family as well. Necitas lives in Pasay City with her husband, Larry C., who is a tricycle operator. They have four children, one of whom is in college while another is in high school.

Ness (as she is fondly called by her friends) presently owns an electronic-loading station for mobile phones and a direct-selling business which caters mainly to people near their residence in Pasay City. E-loading and direct selling of beauty products and other items depends largely on Ness’ perseverance and social connections. Ness and Larry gather a net income of 10,910 Philippine pesos monthly, which they use to meet the needs of the entire family.

Ness admits that she needs a 20,000 pesos loan to enhance her business and increase her profits. She applied to CCT* for this loan, which she plans to use to further her e-loading business as well as her direct-selling business, which includes brands such as Natasha and MSE. She also intends to put up a purified drinking water station with the loan she hopefully will receive from Kiva. Basically, the loan will serve as additional capital that will enable Ness to make her business more profitable and lead to more savings.

At present, Ness sees that her business is not that profitable. She also experiences persecution from people who put her down instead of supporting her in achieving a better life for her family. Still, Ness is determined not to be swayed by these struggles and aims to make her business grow. She prays to find a commercial area where her business could thrive and flourish. She also hopes that her business, along with the purified drinking water station which she plans to put up, will expand and become stable. More important, she dreams of seeing her children finish their studies and be used as one family for the glory of the Lord whom they serve.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Replenishment of cell phone electronic load and advanced orders for her customers

loans.name: Rozina's Group

texts.en:
Rozina is the wife of A. K.. They both reside in a city called Multan, which is famous for its hot weather and history, in Pakistan. 

A very caring and happy-natured lady, Rozina stays at home; she loves to cook food for her family and take care of them. She manages the household chores in an efficient way and gives the required time to her kids. 

Her 55-year-old husband belongs to a dairy business. He has a buffalo that produces 8 to 10 kilograms of milk per day. He sells 1kg of milk for approximately 45 Pakistan rupees (PKR), so his average income is 360-450 PKR per day. He is the only breadwinner of his family and this makes him worry about how his family would survive if something happened to him.
  
Therefore, Rozina has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy a dairy cow and increases his milk-selling business. The purpose of buying a cow is to sell more milk and save money for the rainy days. The saved amount will help them to run the financial circle smoothly and will improve the living standard of the family as well.

loans.name: Shakeela's Group

texts.en:
Shakeela is 50 years old, married, and resides in a city called Multan, which is famous  in Pakistan for its history. She is an uneducated lady who couldn’t study because her parents were in a financial crisis. Her mother is a talented lady. She transferred her talent of sewing to her daughter, Shakeela. Shakeela independently started doing this work after her marriage. She got a two-room house by making a financial investment from her income into her husband’s income.  

Her husband, F. H., is a private entrepreneur, dealing with vegetables & fruits. He purchases them from the market and sells them in different areas and communities. He has six years of experience in this business. He has good knowledge about his products. His customers are very satisfied buying fruits & vegetables from him. His income grows specially in the month of Ramadan (which has already come and people have started keeping the fast).  

Shakeela has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy fruits & vegetables in bulk so he meets the requirements of his customers by having enough items to sell.

loans.use: Purchase seasonal fruits & vegetables for resale

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim is a 38-year-old married woman, resided in a city called Multan famous in Pakistan for its history. She owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family for over fifteen years.  

A very caring lady, Shamim stays at home to do her best for her family. She cooks food for her family and takes care of her children. This is her daughter who is seated next to her. She has a dream to send her to school to make her future bright.
  
Shamim's husband's name is M. L. and he runs an embroidery business. He makes embroidered dresses and displays them in his boutique which is located in the market. He has two helpers in his shop who help him in completing more varieties of embroidery. He has been doing this work for over ten years. He purchases the cloth from the cities Lahore and Faisalabad because these two cities are famous for their textiles and new designs as well.  

Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount he will purchase embroidery materials such as beads, colored thread and especially cloth of different sorts in bulk, making them unique by  doing embroidery on them. She hopes that this investment will prove successful for her husband’s business and he will be able to sell more of his collection to his customers and generate good profit from it.

loans.use: purchase embroidery materials for her husband's embroidery business

loans.name: Divina

texts.en:
Divina L. is from the town of Rizal West, San Isidro. She is 53 years old. Divina is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Divina owns & operates a business selling fruits and vegetables. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables to the local community. Divina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Divina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Divina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials needed to grow produce for sale. Divina is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials needed to grow produce for sale. This will be the 10th loan taken out by Divina from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Sear

texts.en:
Mr. Sear S. is 24 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sreymao S., is 21 years old. She and her husband have been married since 2007 and have only one young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sear has been a fisherman for two years. He fishes from the river and lake near his house. His wife sells fish that her husband catches. He is asking for his first loan of US$ 400 to purchase a boat and fishing materials for his fishing business.  

Sear is not in the photo; he is replaced by his wife.

loans.use: To purchase a boat and fishing materials for his fishing business.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent M. is from the city of San Jose, Santiago City. He is 23 years old. Vincent is single. To make a living, Vincent owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. The main source of income for the business comes from selling kitchen supplies, DVDs, and raincoats. Vincent has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2,400 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Vincent joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vincent has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Vincent is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Vincent from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim N. (pictured above) and her husband, Mr. Chhay Lun, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh about 25 kilometers away. They have been married since 1973 and have nine children--four sons and five daughters. Five of them are married and live outside the family home. One sells groceries at home and other three attend school. 
 
Sim sells ice at home. Her husband has been operating a business renting out a wedding and ceremony hall for four years. Sim is asking for her first loan of US$ 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for her children to drive to school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her children to drive to school.

loans.name: Saeeda's Group

texts.en:
Saeeda is a 40-year-old married woman. She resides in a city called Multan, famous in Pakistan for its history. She is a good-natured woman who always spreads happiness in her surroundings. She is a vigorous lady. She not only manages her clothes business but also handles her domestic chores very efficiently.  

Although she is not educated, she wants to give her kids better education facilities so they make their future bright and become successful in their own lives. She is a very disciplined lady and she has brought up her kids with good manners and taught them to respect their elders. 

Her husband's name is L. and he is also involved in a clothes business. They both have selected their area of selling clothes. Saeeda sells clothes to her community people and he sells cloth to the cloth markets. In this way they generate income for the family. Saeeda’s husband purchases the clothes from different markets of Multan at cheap rates and sells them at a good price. They have been doing this work for over ten years. 

Saeeda has applied for a loan from Asasah for her family business. With the loan amount they will buy clothes in bulk and expand their clothes businesses.

loans.use: Purchase clothes for reselling

loans.name: Sroy

texts.en:
Mrs. Sroy H. (her daughters are in the photo), is 34 years old and her husband, Mr. Lavi Ly, is 37 years old. They live in a small village along National Road Number Five about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1998 and have four children--two sons and two daughters. All of them are in school.  

Sroy sells cake at the local school. Her husband is a construction worker. In addition, the couple is hired by their villagers to produce Khmer noodles. They do not have their own transportation for commuting which costs them a lot of money. 

Therefore, Sroy is applying for her first loan of US$ 600 to purchase a motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin A. is from the village of Villa Concepcion, Cauayan City, Isabela. He is 38 years old. Edwin is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Edwin owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling scrap metal & other used goods like beverage bottles in the local community. Edwin has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,300 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edwin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edwin is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Edwin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sreypov

texts.en:
Mrs. Sreypov H. (in the photo) is 24 years old, and her husband, Mr. Vichet Chhe, is 28 years old. They have been married since 2006 and have just one young son. They are living in a small village across the Mekong River and approximately twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Sreypov has been a silk weaver for six years, while her husband has been a construction worker for five years. She is asking for her first loan, in the amount of $700. She will use $200 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. And she will use the other $500 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials for her weaving business and to buy a motorcycle for her husband to get work

loans.name: Ronilo

texts.en:
Ronilo M. is from the village of Santa Isabel Norte, Ilagan. He is 44 years old. Ronilo is married and has 4 school-age children. To make a living, Ronilo owns and operates a business raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice to sell. Ronilo has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest for these activities.

In 2010, Ronilo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronilo is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ronilo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Channy

texts.en:
Mrs. Channy N. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Leanseng Hun, have been married since 2000 and have one son who is attending school. They are living on an island in the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Channy used to sell vegetables, but she quit because her business was not doing well. She is now a garment factory worker. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver for more than 2 years. Channy has already asked for one Kiva loan to replace her husband's motorbike with a new one. She is now asking for her second loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to get to work

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap P. (pictured with her loom) and her husband were married in 2002 and have two children, one son and one daughter. Their daughter attends school, but their the son is yet too young to do so. They live on an island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. Sopheap has been a silk weaver since 1990 and taught her husband to become a silk weaver as well. He is also a fisherman. Sopheap is applying for a loan of $200 to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Dinia

texts.en:
Dinia D., from the village of Brgy. Malasin, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya, is 41 years old, married, and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Dinia owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products to the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Dinia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Dinia plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Sophak

texts.en: Mr. Sophak S. and his wife, Mrs. Sophea Lok, have been married since 1999 and have three children, one son and two daughters. One attends school and the other two stay at home. Residing in a village approximately 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City, Sophak grows corn and eggplant on his farmland. Having received and repaid a previous loan, he is now requesting a loan of $1000 to start a new business selling cows and oxen. Sophak will use the extra income earned to better support his family.

loans.use: To buy cows and oxen for resale.

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.en: Gulnara K. is a resident of Balykchi, a nice town in Isykul region. Gulnara is 48 years old and she is divorced. She has a 15-year-old daughter and a 12-year-old son, both in school. Ten years ago, with the initial investment of 3000 soms ,Gulnara started a business purchasing milk in villages (about 30 liters per day) and selling it at the market for a profit. She is requesting a loan to purchase kitchen furniture which will improve her family's living conditions. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase kitchen furniture

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina P. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has 5 adult-aged children. Rufina owns and operates a general store and sells a variety of products in the local community. Rufina has been engaged in her business for over 10 years.

Rufina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rufina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Rufina is requesting a new loan of 18000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Rufina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Rysalat

texts.en: Rysalat A., a 57-year-old widow, is a resident of Balykchi, a nice town in Isykul region. She has raised two daughters, both of whom work as cook assistants in a restaurant. For 15 years, Rysalat takes orders for and prepares various foods at her home, and she has developed her own permanent client base. She is requesting a loan to purchase flour and vegetables oil for making cookies and to begin repairing and installing new gates in her house. In the future, she plans to open a café near her home. ====================================== --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase flour,oil and to install new gates in home

loans.name: Ziyomiddin

texts.ru: Мамидов Зиёмиддин проживает в районе Кубадиян. Возраст, 34 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Зиёмиддин имеет среднее образование. У него дилерский центр, он в основном занимается пополнением балансов и продажей сим карт. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 5 лет. Кредит берет для расширения сферы деятельности. Он хочет закупить новые сим карты и карты для пополнения балансов.
texts.en:
Ziyomiddin M. lives in Qubadiyon. He is 34 years old, married, and has four children. His wife is a housewife. Ziyomiddin has a high school education. He has a cell phone kiosk. He primarily works adding minutes to cell phones and selling SIM cards. He has been doing this for five years. He is taking out a loan to expand his business. He wants to buy new SIM cards and new cards which add minutes to phones.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en:
Wilfredo B. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 51 years old, married, and has 6 adult-aged children. Wilfredo owns and operates a fishing business, and he gathers and sells seaweeds to the market. 

Wilfredo joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilfredo has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Wilfredo is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to purchase a pump fishing boat which will improve his fishing business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a fishing boat

loans.name: Romanita

texts.en:
Romanita C. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has 4 school-aged children. Romanita owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of products in the local community. Romanita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years. A few months back, she invested in seaweed farming and she hopes this new venture to grow as well.

Romanita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romanita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Romanita is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her seaweed farming business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Romanita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

“Asenso Loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop.  CEVI recognises the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress.  

CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills.  Please help us provide support for these clients”

loans.use: To invest in expanding her seaweed farming business

loans.name: Amos Kungu

texts.en: Amos Kungu is 25 years old and supports a family of two. His spouse, Jane Njeri, is a business woman contributing an income of five thousand KS per month. Amos has a store selling second-hand clothing on a busy street in Narok town. He mostly deals in men’s wear, especially jackets and shoes. He has been in this business for five years. He learned about KADET through a friend who is already a registered member of KADET micro-finance. This will be his first loan with which he is planning to increase his stock of clothes, specifically men’s trousers. He hopes to use the anticipated profit from this loan to expand his business and opening another clothes shop. Amos dreams of becoming a wholesaler and open up a boutique shop catering to both men and women. He is a hard-working man with a great vision.

loans.use: to buy more clothes, specifically men’s trousers.

loans.name: Agnes Wangari

texts.en: Agnes Wangari Nyabura is 36 years old. She is married and the mother of two children, one ten and the other eight. She is a business woman who sells jeans on a busy street in Narok town. She has run this business for the last five years. She learned about KADET from other women already registered as clients. This will be her third loan. She is planning to increase her stock by buying more jeans. With the profits she hopes to make from the proceeds of this loan, she plans to rent a permanent shop where she can sell her clothes, and to open another shop to create employment for other people. Her dream is to build her own house and run the shop at her own premises. Agnes believes she is hard working and only needs the resources to attain her goals.

loans.use: She is planning to increase her stock by buying more jeans.

loans.name: Bellaflor

texts.en:
Bellaflor L. is from the village of Brgy. Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 42 and married with four school-aged children. To make a living, Bellaflor owns & operates a business providing plumbing repairs. Bellaflor has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Bellaflor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase materials needed to provide service. This will be the first loan taken out by Bellaflor from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Nataana  Ene

texts.en:
Nataana Ene S. is 32 years old and supports three members of her family. Her spouse is Maripet S. and they are blessed with two children aged ten and five. She has been doing wheat farming for the last ten years — successfully due to good climatic condition and a ready market for the produce in her area.
 
With this, her fifth loan, she is planning to spend thirty thousand to buy fertilizer and chemicals for her ten-acre wheat farm and the remaining ten thousand on spraying the wheat. With the anticipated profits she will expand her wheat farming. Her dream is to become a large-scale farmer and own some farm machinery. She is a hard-working woman and determined to achieve her set target

loans.use: fertilizer and chemicals for her ten-acre wheat farm

loans.name: Rapheal

texts.en:
Rapheal is a 41-year-old man who is married with five children aged from 2 to 17 years. He looks after his aged mother and his wife runs a small business of her own. He lives with his family in his own home in Hoima, Uganda.

Rapheal wishes in future to have a family that is self-reliant without loans. He is currently into a timber business and has been in it for ten years. He has a certificate in carpentry and joinery. He at first was working with the diocese and then saved to start his own business.
 
Rapheal faces the hardship of creditors who end up defaulting on payment. He wants his business in future to be a full carpentry shop with machines. He wants a loan to purchase timber for his carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase wood for his carpentry business

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Adoracion C. is from the village of Luna. She is 49 and married with five school-aged children. To make a living, Adoracion runs a general store. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Adoracion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase additional products to sell. Adoracion is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Adoracion from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
This is Lourdes D., 56, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rodrigo D., a cook. They are blessed in their marriage with fine and healthy physiques and contentment in their business.

Lourdes operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5-Philippine-pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. Juanita earns by getting supplies at a wholesale price and selling at a piece rate. Juanita’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php29,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for three years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings*.  

She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Lourdes dreams that her business will be a stable source of income for her and her husband.


**All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of products like groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Bukono Tukore, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Francis N., aged 34 years, is a married father with a family of five children. He has been operating a retail shop from the Bukono trading center, selling general merchandise for over three years. This is the business he started after dropping his previous coffee-selling business.

In here, he trades in a variety of products commonly for domestic use like sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil, paraffin and much more merchandise, earning him a profit of 320,000 Ugandan shillings. His main drawback is that he has limited stock of products in his shop and cannot satisfy the customers' demand. Therefore, Francis is looking forward to increasing stock in his business when he gets this loan and also expanding into a wholesale shop. This will help him earn more revenue and sustain his daily life needs as he envisions improving his family’s standards of living, further educating his children and also buying land for farming in the future.

He belongs to a group of members who hold one another accountable in paying back the loan.

loans.use: Buy more stock for resale

loans.name: Avegail

texts.en:
Avegail T. is 28 years old and a good mother to her two minor children. She is married to her compassionate spouse, Allan, a driver and electrician. They currently live at green farm place, Pandan, Antique. She has been engaged in a hog-fattening business for more than seven years and also gets involved in farming as another source of household income.

She plans to utilize this loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos to expand her hog-fattening business and her farming and to continue to be involved in other businesses for supplementary profits. This loan will be used to pay for a rice thresher and to support the maintenance of raising hogs. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty.

During her seven years as a member of ASHI, Avegail has shown very good performance with her group mates and in her center. Having this loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a successful business, to fund the educational needs of her children until they finish college, to have a better life and a happy family as well. She is very thankful to ASHI and Kiva services for the continued support of her dreams.

loans.use: To pay for a rice thresher and support the maintenance of her hogs

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose B. is 19 years old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, who are all currently in school. Rose has a business running a small hotel, which she has had for less than one year.

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more things like cups, saucepans and plates. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Rose hopes to generate greater profits and to provide her children with things like medication, food, and clothing. In the future, Rose hopes to own a house.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills. Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses. These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance. Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more plates, cups, and saucepans

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en:
This is Marivic O., 31, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, the Philippines. She is married to Ramil O.. They are blessed in their marriage with good health and strong physiques, enough for them to work hard and prepare for their future together.

Marivic operates a general merchandise store. She sells not only the usual groceries, toiletries and beverages, but also Liquefied Petroleum Gas for fuel. She also offers printing services in their little store. Marivic’s store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 29,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like more LPG. She also will replenish her printing supplies. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. She has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for 3 years now, and regularly attends fellowship meetings.*

Marivic hopes to be successful in life through her business.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products, such as LPG (gas) to sell. She also will replenish her printing supplies.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion M. is from the village of Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 48 years old. Salvacion is married and has five adult children. To make a living, Salvacion owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling vegetables, such as string beans and squash, to the local community. Salvacion has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Salvacion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salvacion is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be Salvacion's third loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand the business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Jo-Ane

texts.en:
This is Jo-Ane S., 39, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Marzan, a painter, and is the mother of a child currently enrolled in elementary school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to support her child’s schooling all the way through college. This is the dream of most Filipino parents like Jo-Ane, as she herself is a college graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents can leave their children. Jo-Ane is a licensed nurse.

Jo-Ane maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. The dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are investing on as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 13,000 in sales every month. Jo-Ane also incorporates frozen cuts of meat and native meat delicacies to her current business inventory. She offers sweetened hams, pork sausages and cured beef.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 29,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy orders for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Jo-Ane has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for four years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings.*

Jo-Ane dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She hopes to see her child receive his own college diploma.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy orders for her customers

loans.name: Hellen Juma

texts.en:
Hellen Juma O. is a woman of thirty-eight years old. Married to Eliud Oyoo and blessed with six children, they live in the road block area in Eldoret town. Her business is in Eldoret town, where she buys fruits like bananas in bulk and sells them in small quantities. Hellen has been in this business for fourteen years now and gets a monthly salary of fifty thousand.

This will be Hellen's second loan from KADET. She plans to use the loan to buy more stock, like bananas and green maize for resale. With the income she is going to get, she plans to pay school fees for her children.

In the future Hellen plans to provide for her children by educating them to the highest level, and providing for their basic needs.

loans.use: To buy more stock for resale

loans.name: Rispha

texts.en:
Rispha J. is a woman of 33 yearsof age, married to Stephen Maiyo and together they have four children. They live in Strawberg in the outskirts of Eldoret town. She has a cafe in the same area where she sells cooked food.  She has been in business for five years and earns a monthly income of six thousand shillings.

This will be Rispha's sixth loan with Kiva partner KADET. She plans to buy cooking fat for 6500 shillings, five trays of eggs, six bundles of baking flour, etc.  She plans to support her children by paying their school fees and buying them food with the additional income she will earn.

In the future she hopes to educate her children to the highest level and also to provide for their basic needs such as food, clothes and shelter.

loans.use: To buy baking flour, eggs, cooking oil etc.

loans.name: Narelie

texts.en:
Narelie A. is from the town of Turod Norte, Cordon. She is 19 years-old and married with a baby.  To make a living, Narelie owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from selling milk and fish in the local community. Narelie has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Narelie joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narelie is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Uranchimeg

texts.en:
Uranchimeg L. is 40 years-old and lives with her two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.  Her son attends the local secondary school and her daughter is a student in the town. In order to make money and improve their quality of life, her husband has been living and working in the USA. 

Uranchimeg operates a bag trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town which is called Sunday Plaza in her town.  She started her business in 2006 and over the years has gained business experience and built a positive reputation amongst her customers and suppliers.  Uranchimeg imports her quality products from Beijing in China so her products are sold at high prices. Uranchimeg plans to expand her business in the near future.  She works very hard to grow her business and increase her earnings as it is the only source of income for her family.  She says, "my one wish is for my children to receive a good education and become good people who can lead their lives without difficulties." She is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to import a variety of bags in bulk from China.

loans.use: To import a variety of bags in bulk.

loans.name: Kyeijanga Wome's, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Hard working and cooperative T. Winfred is married with four children of her own to take care of and knows that she has her tasks cut out for her.  This reality has looked her in the face for the past nine years as she has gone about her general retail shop business.  Her shop sells general merchandise particularly items for home use and she also does a side business in liquor sales from Kyeijanga, Kihihi. 

With her monthly earnings of 320,000 Ugandan shillings, she has faced long odds in providing for all her family’s needs and principally catering for her children’s welfare as her husband is negligent. Winfred wants to improve the living status of her family through the acquisition of this loan and plans to give her business an improved lease on life by expanding. Through restocking her shop with a vision of making it a wholesale business, she hopes to earn increased sales revenue and to be able to pay the education bills for her children.

loans.use: To restock her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
N. Maria is 16 years-old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is unmarried and has no children.   For the last three years, Maria has had a business of selling shoes.         

To help expand her business, Maria has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase to buy more shoes.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Maria hopes to generate greater profits and to take care of herself by buying food and clothes.  In the future, Maria hopes to own a house and a vehicle.    

Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.  Initially, the ELA program provides disadvantaged adolescents, particularly girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and to give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more shoes.

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en: Rowena R. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old. Rowena is single. To make a living, Rowena raises crops. The main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Rowena also started growing pigs for fattening. She hopes to expand her new venture and plans to buy additional piglets. Rowena joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP), which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional piglets. This will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training programs through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and additional piglets

loans.name: Enhsaihan

texts.en:
Enhsaihan S. lives with her son and mother in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. She and her family live together in an one-room apartment in the city. Her son currently attends a district primary school and her mother helps her out with her clothing-sales business. 

Enhsaihan manages a clothing and consumer goods trading business out of a stall at a local market. She sells a variety of clothing items, such as women's clothing and lingerie. After graduating university with a major in market research, Enhsaihan started her own business selling consumer goods in 2004.  

After several years of stable earnings, she used her savings to expand her business and began renting another stall at Mars, the biggest market in her town and where she currently manages her operation. Her working capital has now reached to 5,000,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) and daily revenue is approximately 60,000-70,000 MNT.  

Enhsaihan is a very hardworking and decent person. She is very focused on making her business successful as it is the only source of income for her family. She says, "My only wish is provide for my son's education and help him to be a better person." 

She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase different clothes so she can expand her product line.

loans.use: To purchase different clothes

loans.name: Bushenyi United Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
In Bushenyi Town, a determined and hardworking Catherine N., aged 28, operates a retail shop business selling general merchandise including basins, jerrycans, buckets, groceries, sugar, salt and more. She started this business four years ago with her own savings and every month is able to earn about 200,000 Ugandan shillings.

Catherine's main business drawback has been inadequate inventory to meet customer demand, so she seeking a loan to enable her to stock more goods and help expand her enterprise. Being very committed to her business and the provision of good customer care, Catherine hopes to increase her sales revenue and ultimately transform hers into a wholesale business that will enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To increase the stock carried in her store

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
This is Cecilia M., 60, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Leandro M., an analyst, and is the mother to a young, hardworking adult.

Cecilia operates a snack stall. She mainly sells "proven," sometimes also known as "chicken proven" or spelled "proben." According to Wikipedia, "proven" is “a type of street food popular in some regions of the Philippines. It consists essentially of the proventriculus (part of the stomach) of a chicken, dipped in cornstarch, and deep-fried. It is served either in a small bagful of vinegar, or skewered on bamboo sticks to be dipped in the vinegar just before it is eaten.” She also sells “palamig,” a kind of sweetened beverage with cut-up gelatin floating in the vanilla flavored drink. Her main customers are her neighbors and her immediate community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos a day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of products like meats, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Cecilia has been a member of Center for Community Transformation for five years now and regularly attends fellowship meetings. 

Cecilia dreams to be able to enjoy a peaceful and successful life through all her hard work on her business. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of products like meats, condiments and seasonings

loans.name: Jeny Vieve

texts.en: Jeny Vieve E. is from the town of Banga. She is 18 years old. Jeny Vieve is single. To make a living, Jeny Vieve operates a family member's business venture of raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. She also helps at their farm. She helps plant and harvest rice crops. She says she is working now to save for her college education. She also dreams to finish college and have a bright future. Jeny Vieve joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jeny Vieve is requesting a new loan of 6,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and farm supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Jeny Vieve from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's business. About CEVI: Community Economic Ventures, Inc., (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social-performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also offers savings, insurance and training programs, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry M. is a hardworking man who runs a music and photo studio in Bushenyi town, dealing in taking photos and selling music tapes, video discs and seasonal cards like for Christmas, Easter and friendship wishes. He is also hired by customers to play music at parties. He began this business eight years ago after dropping out of school due to tuition-fee problems.

He envisions expanding his business with more stock of goods with the loan coming his way, which will help him capture the customers’ attention and further improve daily sales. His major dream is to live a self-sustaining life in the near future.

He is the father of a 5-year-old child and a bright future is what he wishes for this child.

loans.use: Increasing business stock

loans.name: Nelyvin Makungu

texts.en:
Nelyvin Makungu S. is a woman of 31 years and a single parent. She lives with four of her relatives in Likuyani in the outskirts of Eldoret. Nelyvin offers motorbike transport to people in Likuyani; she has also employed a young man to help in her transportation work. Most of her customers are her neighbors. She has been in this business for two years and she gets a monthly income of 15,000 shillings.

Nelyvin will be taking her second loan with KADET and she plans to use the loan to buy new spare parts and carry out major repairs for her motorbike and also to buy new iron sheets for roofing her house.

With the profit she is going to get, she plans to buy another motorbike to increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy spare parts for the motorbike

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma M. is 56 years old and lives in Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Jerry M., an overseas Filipino worker, and and has  four children, one of whom is already working while the other three are still in school. At this time, she is working hard so that she can send her remaining children to college.  As an elementary graduate Norma believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Norma operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, such as round palm-sized ones to much larger doormats, braided quilts, bed sheets, and other crafts. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials, including fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Norma dreams of giving her children a high quality education through all her hard work with her business.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread, and newspapers for patterns

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. is 21 years-old and lives in the town of Kireka in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is married and has three children.  Two of her children are currently in school.  For the last four years, Margret has had a business of a beauty salon.         

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase to buy more oil and braids for hair.  With the help of the loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food for her family.  In the future, Margret hopes to educate her children through to university.             

Note to lenders: 

BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan.  Initially, the ELA program provides disadvantaged adolescents, in particular girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterwards, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age, improve their prospects for the future and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and in giving Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more oil and braids for the hair.

loans.name: Jona

texts.en:
Jona A. is from the town of Roxas Cordon Isabela. She is 29 years –old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Jona owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jona has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 8,200 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jona joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Jona is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jona from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Tobiko Ole

texts.en:
Tobiko ole N. is 38 years-old.  He is married to Pariote N. and he is a father of four children.  Tobiko is a wheat farmer and, for the last ten years, he has farmed on his own piece of land.

He learned about Kiva partner KADET through a friend who is a KADET registered client in his area of residence. This will be his first loan and he plans to spend the fifteen thousand buying seeds and fertilizer. 

He hopes to use the profit generated from this loan to reinvest on the farm and plant a bigger piece of land with wheat.

Tobiko's dream is to do large scale farming and attain financial independence.

He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph G. is from the town of Banga. He is 31 years-old and unmarried. To make a living, Joseph owns and operates a business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over five years. He says he works hard to save for his future family as he plans to have his own family someday.

Joseph joined Kiva partner CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Joseph is requesting a first loan in the amount of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly in recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training which is provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, seedlings and young crops.

loans.name: Esunjol

texts.en:
Esunjol T. is 28 years-old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayan-Ulgiy province, western Mongolia. His two children are too young to attend a school so they stay at home and his wife helps him out with his fruit selling business. Since 2004, Esunjol has been operating two types of businesses from rented stalls at a local trade market - fruit retailing and furniture sales. 

Esunjol started his business with a working capital of 1,500,000 MNT but after several years of stable earnings, he used his savings to expand his business.  The working capital now exceeds 3,5000,000 MNT and he was able to purchase a truck for his business. Esunjol is a hard working and polite person who wishes to buy a small car as well.  He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a large quantity of fruit and vegetables for his business from Hovd, a neighbouring province of Bayan-Ulgiy.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of fruit and vegetables.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita B. is from the village of San Pablo, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 44 years old. Carmelita is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2007, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Carmelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

<b>About ASKI:<b>

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital
